question_text: A 55-year-old woman loses consciousness in the emergency department one hour after being admitted to the hospital for sharp, acute chest pain and diaphoresis. There are no palpable pulses. Chest compressions are started. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and breast cancer that was surgically treated 4 years ago. Prior to admission, the patient was on a long bus ride to visit her sister. Her medications include tamoxifen, atorvastatin, metoprolol, metformin, and insulin. The cardiac rhythm is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 55-year-old woman loses consciousness in the emergency department one hour after being admitted to the hospital for sharp, acute chest pain and diaphoresis. There are no palpable pulses. Chest compressions are started. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and breast cancer that was surgically treated 4 years ago. Prior to admission, the patient was on a long bus ride to visit her sister. Her medications include tamoxifen, atorvastatin, metoprolol, metformin, and insulin. The cardiac rhythm is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The absence of pulses in this patient indicates cardiac arrest. The presence of a sinus rhythm on the cardiac monitor suggests pulseless electrical activity (PEA).
learning_objective: Recognize pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, and choose the most appropriate medication in cardiac arrest management.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous glucagon is recommended for patients with suspected beta blocker toxicity. Although this patient takes metoprolol and has some features of beta blocker toxicity (e.g., hypotension, bradycardia), the absence of PR interval prolongation is inconsistent with beta blocker toxicity. Other features, such as wheezing or seizures, are also not present. Regardless of the underlying etiology, she is currently in PEA arrest and requires a different emergent therapy.

Defibrillation is indicated for patients with cardiac arrest due to ventricular tachycardia (usually appearing as a wide-complex, regular tachycardia) or ventricular fibrillation (usually appearing as a wide-complex, irregular tachycardia). Defibrillation is not recommended for patients in PEA arrest.

Acute myocardial infarction is an important cause of cardiac arrest, and coronary angiography should be considered once the patient is resuscitated. While evaluating the underlying cause of this patient's arrest will eventually be important, she is too unstable to undergo coronary angioplasty.

The next best step for this patient in PEA arrest is administration of epinephrine (given as 1 mg IV, and repeated every 3–5 minutes while continuing CPR). PEA arrest is characterized by continued electrical activity within the cardiac conduction system (as seen in this patient with sinus rhythm on the cardiac monitor) but inadequate cardiac output to support tissue perfusion. For this reason, PEA arrest is considered a nonshockable rhythm. High-quality chest compressions and IV epinephrine are vital aspects of management.

IV amiodarone is a second-line agent used in patients with cardiac arrest due to ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation who have not responded to first-line strategies (e.g., epinephrine, defibrillation). It is administered as a 300 mg bolus and an additional 150 mg dose can be given 3–5 minutes later. Amiodarone is not recommended for patients in PEA arrest.

Therapeutic hypothermia is recommended when there is impaired mental status (e.g., not following commands, no purposeful movements) after the return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) has been achieved in a patient with cardiac arrest. It has been shown to improve neurological outcomes in post-cardiac arrest patients and is recommended for at least 24 hours. Hypothermia therapy is not indicated for this patient who has not yet achieved ROSC.

Although hypoglycemia is not a typical cause of PEA arrest, it is common postarrest (along with other metabolic derangements). Therefore, this patient's serum glucose should be closely monitored after resuscitation. However, she currently lacks a perfusing blood pressure (as evidenced by her lack of pulse and mental status), which requires a different emergent intervention at this time.

images.title: Sinus bradycardia
images.description:
ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Regular sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 37/min
– PR interval normal (∼ 160 ms), QRS normal (∼ 110 ms), QT interval normal (∼ 480 ms; QTc = 380 ms)
– Morphologies of P wave, QRS complex, and T wave are physiologic. Note the U waves (occurring after the T waves).
– No signs of ischemia

question_text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of right-sided abdominal pain. He has had nausea and vomiting on occasion during this time. He has not had altered bowel habits or weight loss. He has had a dog for the last 8 years. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows a nontender mass 3 cm below the right costal margin that moves with respiration. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
14.6 g/dL

Leukocyte count
7,200/mm^3

 Segmented neutrophils
58%

 Eosinophils

8%

 Lymphocytes
30%

 Monocytes
4%

Ultrasound of the abdomen shows a focal hypoechoic cyst within the liver measuring 7 cm. An ELISA confirms the diagnosis. He is scheduled for CT-guided percutaneous drainage under general anesthesia with orotracheal intubation. Seven minutes into the procedure, the patient's oxygen saturation suddenly decreases from 95% to 64%. His heart rate is 136/min, and blood pressure is 86/58 mm Hg. No end-tidal CO_2 waveform is seen on capnography. Breath sounds are absent bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of right-sided abdominal pain. He has had nausea and vomiting on occasion during this time. He has not had altered bowel habits or weight loss. He has had a dog for the last 8 years. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows a nontender mass 3 cm below the right costal margin that moves with respiration. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 14.6 g/dL Leukocyte count 7,200/mm3 Segmented neutrophils 58% Eosinophils 8% Lymphocytes 30% Monocytes 4% Ultrasound of the abdomen shows a focal hypoechoic cyst within the liver measuring 7 cm. An ELISA confirms the diagnosis. He is scheduled for CT-guided percutaneous drainage under general anesthesia with orotracheal intubation. Seven minutes into the procedure, the patient's oxygen saturation suddenly decreases from 95% to 64%. His heart rate is 136/min, and blood pressure is 86/58 mm Hg. No end-tidal CO2 waveform is seen on capnography. Breath sounds are absent bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Based on his right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, close contact with a dog, eosinophilia, and focal cyst within the liver, the diagnosis in this patient is most likely hydatid cyst disease. The contents of a hydatid cyst are highly antigenic.
learning_objective: Recognize anaphylaxis during a procedure for hydatid cyst disease, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Exploratory laparotomy would be indicated if intra-abdominal hemorrhage occurred as a result of damage to intra-abdominal vessels during percutaneous drainage. Patients with intra-abdominal hemorrhage may present with hypotension and tachycardia. However, hypoxemia, a sudden decrease in end tidal CO2, and the absence of breath sounds bilaterally on auscultation suggest a different cause of shock. Moreover, the risk of intra-abdominal hemorrhage during CT-guided cyst drainage is extremely low.

Epinephrine is the treatment of choice for anaphylaxis. The patient underwent a CT-guided PAIR (puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration) procedure, during which he developed hypotension, tachycardia, decreased oxygen saturation, and severe bronchospasm (as evident by a sudden decrease in end tidal CO_2 and absent breath sounds). These features suggest anaphylaxis, which is probably the result of leakage of highly antigenic cystic fluid into blood or the peritoneal cavity.
Cricothyrotomy is not indicated in this patient because the airway is already secured by an endotracheal tube.

A pneumothorax or hemothorax may rarely occur as a result of inadvertent diaphragmatic puncture during percutaneous drainage of a hepatic cyst. Patients with severe pneumothorax or hemothorax can present with hypoxemia, tachycardia, and decreased breath sounds. However, breath sounds would only be absent on the right side. The absence of a capnography waveform and bilateral breath sounds suggests a different diagnosis.

Norepinephrine is used for inotropic support for patients with cardiogenic shock, which may occur following massive pulmonary thromboembolism. Although rare, pulmonary thromboembolism can occur during percutaneous cyst drainage. Patients with pulmonary embolism may present with tachycardia, hypotension, and a decrease in end tidal CO_2, as seen here. However, breath sounds would not be affected, and the presence of a silent chest in this patient indicates a different diagnosis.

question_text:
A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He is obtunded on arrival. He is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. The ventilator is set at an FiO_2 of 60%, tidal volume of 440 mL, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 7 cm H_2O. On the third day of intubation, his temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 103/60 mm Hg. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:

pH
7.49

pCO_2

29 mm Hg

pO_2

73 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

20 mEq/L

O_2 saturation
89%

Monitoring shows a sudden increase in the plateau airway pressure. An x-ray of the chest shows deepening of the costophrenic angle on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He is obtunded on arrival. He is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. The ventilator is set at an FiO2 of 60%, tidal volume of 440 mL, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 7 cm H2O. On the third day of intubation, his temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 103/60 mm Hg. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Arterial blood gas analysis shows: pH 7.49 pCO2 29 mm Hg pO2 73 mm Hg HCO3- 20 mEq/L O2 saturation 89% Monitoring shows a sudden increase in the plateau airway pressure. An x-ray of the chest shows deepening of the costophrenic angle on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Decreased breath sounds, increased airway pressure, respiratory alkalosis, and deep sulcus sign on chest x-ray in a mechanically ventilated patient indicate a pneumothorax.
learning_objective: Recognize the signs of pneumothorax in a mechanically ventilated patient, and choose the most appropriate intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Immediate insertion of a large-bore needle into the 2^nd intercostal space along the midclavicular line or the 4^th–5^th intercostal space between the anterior and midaxillary line is indicated for tension pneumothorax. Although tension pneumothorax may also manifest with decreased oxygen saturation and deep sulcus sign, further findings such as contralateral tracheal deviation, distended neck veins, cyanosis, and hemodynamic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension) are commonly seen.

Respiratory fluoroquinolones such as levofloxacin are the first-line treatment in patients with hospital-acquired pneumonia who do not have risk factors for multiresistant pathogens (e.g., prior antibiotic treatment, structural lung disease). Pneumonia typically manifests with high fever and chills, productive cough, tachypnea, and dyspnea. Chest x-ray usually shows extensive opacities restricted to one pulmonary lobe, poorly defined patchy infiltrates, or diffuse reticular opacity. These features are not present in this patient.

Increasing the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is often necessary when treating acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Patients with ARDS typically present with acute onset tachypnea, tachycardia, cyanosis, dyspnea, diffuse crackles, and possibly fever, cough, and chest pain. Chest x-ray of patients with ARDS usually reveals diffuse bilateral infiltrates, air bronchogram, atelectasis, and pleural effusions. This patient's x-ray indicates a pneumothorax, most likely due to increased pressures during mechanical ventilation. Increasing the PEEP is contraindicated as it would exacerbate his condition.

Insertion of a chest tube into the 4^th–5^th intercostal space between the anterior and midaxillary line (safe triangle) is the most appropriate next step for treating pneumothorax in a mechanically ventilated patient. Mechanical ventilation (especially with a high positive end-expiratory pressure) is considered a risk factor for developing pneumothorax. High ventilatory pressure can damage the lung tissue, causing a leak that allows air to enter the pleural cavity. Because the air entering the pleural space comes from the lung rather than the exterior, it is known as a closed pneumothorax. Following completion of the procedure, another chest x-ray to control the position of chest tube placement should be performed. To prevent further lung damage, the ventilatory pressure should be decreased.

Pneumothorax is often hard to diagnose in ventilated patients. Since the x-ray is obtained in the supine position, less air collects apically, making the pneumothorax less obvious.

Indications to obtain a CT scan include uncertain diagnosis despite chest x-ray, suspected underlying lung disease (to determine likelihood of recurrent disease), and presurgical workup. The patient had a chest x-ray that showed deepening of the costophrenic angle, indicating a pneumothorax. Further workup with a chest CT is not needed at this time.

Close observation would be the most appropriate next step in the management of asymptomatic patients with a small primary spontaneous pneumothorax (rim between the lung edge and chest wall < 2–3 cm). Such a pneumothorax usually resolves spontaneously within ∼ 10 days and symptomatic treatment and serial follow-up with repeat chest x-ray are sufficient. This patient is symptomatic, presenting with iatrogenic pneumothorax most likely due to mechanical ventilation, and requires treatment.

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and vomiting for 8 hours. He has had around 3–4 episodes of greenish-colored vomit during this period. He has major depressive disorder with psychosis. His mother has Graves disease. Current medications include sertraline and haloperidol. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. He is diagnosed with acute appendicitis and is taken to the operating room for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. The appendix is gangrenous and perforated, and there is purulent fluid in the pelvis. Just after the appendiceal base is ligated, the patient develops muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The end-tidal CO_2 is markedly increased. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and vomiting for 8 hours. He has had around 3–4 episodes of greenish-colored vomit during this period. He has major depressive disorder with psychosis. His mother has Graves disease. Current medications include sertraline and haloperidol. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. He is diagnosed with acute appendicitis and is taken to the operating room for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. The appendix is gangrenous and perforated, and there is purulent fluid in the pelvis. Just after the appendiceal base is ligated, the patient develops muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The end-tidal CO2 is markedly increased. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient developed an acute increase in body temperature associated with tachycardia, muscle rigidity, and a marked increase in end-tidal CO_2 after receiving anesthesia, which is indicative of malignant hyperthermia.
learning_objective: Recognize malignant hyperthermia, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Propranolol is the treatment of choice for a thyrotoxic crisis. In patients with untreated hyperthyroidism, acute stress (e.g., infection or surgery) may precipitate a thyrotoxic crisis. In an anesthetized patient, thyrotoxic crisis manifests with fever, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and/or hypertension. Muscle rigidity, as seen here, is not a typical feature of a thyrotoxic crisis. In addition, this patient has no preoperative clinical features that suggest a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism, despite the family history of Graves disease.

Dantrolene is the drug of choice to treat malignant hyperthermia because it prevents generalized muscle contraction by decreasing the concentration of calcium within the muscle cytoplasm. Physiologically, calcium induces contraction of muscle cells, and in the absence of intracellular calcium, muscle fibers cannot contract. An increase in end-tidal CO_2 is usually the earliest sign of malignant hyperthermia. It reflects increased production of CO_2 (due to accelerated aerobic metabolism) and, subsequently, serum lactate (as a result of the change in anaerobic metabolism), which together cause mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.

Management of patients with malignant hyperthermia includes immediate cessation of potential triggering agents (e.g, volatile anesthetics), hyperventilation with 100% O_2_, and cooling measures (e.g., ice packs, ice lavage). Susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia can be determined by a caffeine halothane contracture test or genetic testing for mutations in the RYR1 and DHP genes.

Bromocriptine is not effective in the treatment of malignant hyperthermia but may be used to treat neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). This patient is taking haloperidol, which may predispose him to develop NMS. While patients with NMS also develop fever, hypertension, tachycardia, and muscle rigidity, the onset of NMS is not hyperacute; instead, NMS evolves gradually over 1–3 days. In addition, it usually occurs within 2 weeks of initiating antipsychotic therapy or increasing dosage.

Empiric combination therapy of antibiotics should be administered in this patient with perforated appendicitis until the bacterial resistance pattern has been determined. Empiric antibiotic therapy in the case of appendicitis must also include coverage of anaerobic bacteria (e.g., Bacteroides spp.), as they are a common pathogen in appendicitis. Ceftriaxone does not have anaerobic coverage, and vancomycin only covers gram-positive anaerobes. A different empiric antibiotic regimen with broad coverage including gram-negative anaerobes would be indicated in this patient (e.g., piperacillin and tazobactam). Moreover, this patient requires therapy for malignant hyperthermia.

Cyproheptadine is the antidote of choice to treat severe serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome may be a complication of therapy with antidepressants, such as sertraline. Although serotonin syndrome may also manifest with hyperthermia, diaphoresis, and muscle hypertonia, it usually occurs after a recent increase in the dose or frequency of antidepressants. This patient has no history of a recent medication change. The absence of other typical features of serotonin syndrome, such as clonus and mydriasis, as well as the marked increase in end-tidal CO_2 suggest a different diagnosis.

Surgical embolectomy may be considered for hemodynamically unstable patients with acute pulmonary embolism (PE) when thrombolysis or anticoagulant therapy is contraindicated (e.g., risk of blood loss during surgery). In an anesthetized patient, PE may manifest with tachycardia. Unlike in this patient, the end-tidal CO_2 should be decreased because of impaired pulmonary perfusion. Also, this patient does not have risk factors associated with PE, such as prolonged immobilization or trauma, and does not display any clinical features of deep vein thrombosis, making this condition even less likely.

question_text: A 4-year old boy is brought to the emergency department with fever, painful swallowing, headache, and neck spasm that began shortly after waking up. He has had a sore throat over the last week that acutely worsened this morning. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He lives at home with his mother. His older brother has asthma. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.2°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 93/60 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is drooling from the mouth. The neck is stiff and extension is limited. Respirations appear labored with accessory muscle use. Inspiratory stridor is heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Oropharyngeal examination shows a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall. Intravenous access is obtained and laboratory studies are ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-year old boy is brought to the emergency department with fever, painful swallowing, headache, and neck spasm that began shortly after waking up. He has had a sore throat over the last week that acutely worsened this morning. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He lives at home with his mother. His older brother has asthma. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.2°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 93/60 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is drooling from the mouth. The neck is stiff and extension is limited. Respirations appear labored with accessory muscle use. Inspiratory stridor is heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Oropharyngeal examination shows a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall. Intravenous access is obtained and laboratory studies are ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with fever, odynophagia, an inability to extend his neck, and a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, all of which suggest retropharyngeal abscess.
learning_objective: Recognize retropharyngeal abscess with impending respiratory compromise, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why:
Emergency airway management is indicated in patients with suspected retropharyngeal abscess who present with features of impending respiratory compromise (e.g., inspiratory stridor, hypoxemia, and labored breathing with accessory muscle use). The patient should be intubated for airway protection and emergency surgical drainage should be performed. If endotracheal intubation is not possible because of severe airway compromise, or if the posterior pharyngeal wall ruptures during intubation, an emergency tracheostomy should be performed to secure the airway.

Airway management to prevent respiratory compromise takes priority in the management of any infection of the deep neck spaces.

Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics like ampicillin-sulbactam and clindamycin can be used to treat retropharyngeal abscesses that present early in clinically stable patients without any airway compromise. This child has severe respiratory distress, requiring a more urgent procedure before antibiotics are administered.

Blood cultures should be drawn from patients with retropharyngeal abscesses to identify the causative pathogen. Airway management to prevent respiratory compromise takes priority in the management of any infection of the deep neck spaces.

Intravenous corticosteroid therapy may be used in combination with antibiotics to reduce inflammation and swelling of the upper airway in a patient with a retropharyngeal abscess. However, this patient is in severe respiratory distress and a more urgent procedure is required.

A CT of the neck can be used to confirm deep neck infections if a lateral neck x-ray is inconclusive. While this child may eventually need a CT of the neck to evaluate the underlying infection and its extent, he is in severe respiratory distress and a more urgent procedure is required.

Nebulized albuterol can be used in patients with respiratory distress caused by bronchospasm (e.g., asthma). This patient’s respiratory distress results from upper airway obstruction due to a retropharyngeal abscess. Therefore, albuterol is not indicated for airway management in this patient.

Lateral neck x-ray can be used as an initial diagnostic modality to confirm retropharyngeal abscess in a clinically stable child. Although the x-ray would most likely show a widened prevertebral space, this child is in severe respiratory distress and a more urgent procedure is required.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for medical clearance for a molar extraction. He feels well. He reports he is able to climb 3 flights of stairs without experiencing any shortness of breath. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and ischemic heart disease. He underwent an aortic valve replacement for severe aortic stenosis last year. Twelve years ago, he underwent a cardiac angioplasty and had 2 stents placed. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 136/82 mm Hg. A mechanical click is heard at the right upper sternal border.  Prothrombin time is 30 seconds (INR = 2.5). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for medical clearance for a molar extraction. He feels well. He reports he is able to climb 3 flights of stairs without experiencing any shortness of breath. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and ischemic heart disease. He underwent an aortic valve replacement for severe aortic stenosis last year. Twelve years ago, he underwent a cardiac angioplasty and had 2 stents placed. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 136/82 mm Hg. A mechanical click is heard at the right upper sternal border. Prothrombin time is 30 seconds (INR = 2.5). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Patients with prosthetic heart valves are at an increased risk for infective endocarditis (IE), particularly when undergoing dental procedures.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for infective endocarditis prophylaxis in patients with prosthetic heart valves undergoing dental procedures, and choose the most appropriate antibiotic regimen.

answers.content: Administer oral amoxicillin 1 hour before the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Antimicrobial prophylaxis for the prevention of IE is recommended for high-risk patients (e.g., patients with prosthetic heart valves, a history of IE, or an unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart defect) who undergo procedures that are likely to result in bacteremia with common pathogens of IE. These procedures include certain dental procedures (e.g., tooth extraction, routine dental cleaning), procedures of the respiratory tract that involve incision of the respiratory mucosa, and cardiac surgery with prosthetic material (e.g., prosthetic heart valves). The most commonly used antibiotic regimen is oral amoxicillin administered 30–60 minutes prior to a high-risk procedure. Alternatives to amoxicillin include intravenous ampicillin in patients unable to take oral medication and azithromycin in patients allergic to penicillin.

Echocardiography is indicated in patients with prosthetic heart valves if a change in clinical symptoms (e.g, a new murmur, new cardiac symptoms) occurs or if valve dysfunction is suspected. Echocardiography is not routinely performed before dental procedures.

answers.content: Avoid nitrous oxide during the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Nitrous oxide (NO) is a general anesthetic used for sedation and analgesia during dental procedures. Contraindications for using NO include known hypersensitivity to NO, history of vitreoretinal surgery, and intraocular gas bubbles (a treatment for retinal detachment), none of which apply to this patient.

answers.content: Discontinue aspirin and warfarin 72 hours prior to procedure
answers.explanation_why: Anticoagulation with a therapeutic INR should be continued in patients with prosthetic heart valves who undergo procedures in which only minor bleeding is expected or bleeding can be easily controlled (e.g., dental procedures, minor dermatologic procedures).

answers.content: Administer oral azithromycin 1 hour before and 2 hours after the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Azithromycin is used as a second-line agent for the prevention of IE in high-risk patients allergic to penicillin. However, this patient has no history of allergies. Moreover, antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely administered following dental procedures.

question_text: Three days after undergoing an open cholecystectomy, a 57-year-old woman has fever, chills, and a headache. She has right-sided chest pain that increases on inspiration and has had a productive cough for the last 12 hours. She had an episode of hypotension after the operation that resolved with intravenous fluid therapy. She underwent an abdominal hysterectomy 16 years ago for multiple fibroids of the uterus. She has hypertension and psoriasis. Prior to being admitted to the hospital, her medications included amlodipine and clobetasol ointment. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 17 years. She appears uncomfortable. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Inspiratory crackles are heard at the right lung base. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a healing surgical incision below the right rib cage. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Three days after undergoing an open cholecystectomy, a 57-year-old woman has fever, chills, and a headache. She has right-sided chest pain that increases on inspiration and has had a productive cough for the last 12 hours. She had an episode of hypotension after the operation that resolved with intravenous fluid therapy. She underwent an abdominal hysterectomy 16 years ago for multiple fibroids of the uterus. She has hypertension and psoriasis. Prior to being admitted to the hospital, her medications included amlodipine and clobetasol ointment. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 17 years. She appears uncomfortable. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Inspiratory crackles are heard at the right lung base. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a healing surgical incision below the right rib cage. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Fever, productive cough, pleuritic chest pain, and crackles are all common features of this postoperative complication, which typically occurs 3–5 days after surgery.
learning_objective: Recognize postoperative pneumonia.

answers.explanation_why: Left heart failure associated with congestive heart failure typically leads to pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, orthopnea, cough), which may resemble those seen in this patient. However, this patient presenting with fever 3 days following surgery is more concerning for an alternative diagnosis.

One of the most important risk factors of pulmonary embolism (PE) is immobility (e.g., following surgery). Clinical presentation is variable, with symptoms including chest pain, coughing, dyspnea, tachycardia, and even obstructive shock. Although this patient presents with chest pain shortly after her surgery, and fever can also be present in PE, productive cough and crackles at the right lung base suggest a different diagnosis. She also has neither tachycardia nor a history of or current signs of deep vein thrombosis (e.g., swelling, tenderness, and/or discoloration of the lower extremities).

Subphrenic abscess may occur when pus accumulates between the spleen, diaphragm, and liver. Subphrenic abscess typically manifests with pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain most commonly around 10 days after surgery. Although the patient has fever, it started 2 days after her operation and she has no other typical features of a subphrenic abscess.

This patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with postoperative pneumonia, a common postsurgical complication that typically manifests 3 to 5 days following surgery. Additionally, this patient has undergone upper abdominal surgery and is a smoker, both of which are predisposing factors. Other known risk factors for postoperative pulmonary complications include thoracic surgery, surgery duration > 3–4 hours, patient age > 50 years, preexisting lung disease, and poor general health status.

Clinical features of atelectasis depend on the severity and extent of atelectasis and range from no symptoms to respiratory distress. Physical examination reveals dullness to percussion and diminished breathing sounds over the affected area. This patient has a productive cough, pleuritic chest pain, and inspiratory crackles, all of which make atelectasis less likely. The role of atelectasis in the postoperative development of fever is controversial; some studies have concluded that the association may be coincidental.

images.title: Causes of atelectasis
images.description:
1. Obstructive atelectasis: foreign body aspiration results in airflow obstruction, poor ventilation, and atelectasis.2. Non-obstructive atelectasis:
A) Compression atelectasis: A pleural effusion causes increased intrathoracic pressure actively forcing air out of the alveoli.
B) Relaxation atelectasis: A pneumothorax disrupts the contact between the visceral and parietal pleurae, resulting in passive atelectasis.
C) Cicatrization atelectasis: Generalized parenchymal fibrosis impairs full expansion of the right lung.
D) Adhesive atelectasis: Increased surface tension due to a deficiency of surfactant leads to generalized alveolar collapse.

answers.explanation_why: Although this patient presents with pleuritic chest pain, she does not have tachycardia, diminished breath sounds, decreased chest excursion, or hyperresonant percussion, which would be expected with pneumothorax. She also presents with fever and productive cough, both of which are inconsistent with pneumothorax.

question_text: An x-ray of the chest shows an extensive consolidation within the right lower lobe consistent with lobar pneumonia. Sputum and blood cultures are sent to the laboratory for analysis, and empiric antibiotic treatment with intravenous cefepime is begun. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's pneumonia?
content_preview: An x-ray of the chest shows an extensive consolidation within the right lower lobe consistent with lobar pneumonia. Sputum and blood cultures are sent to the laboratory for analysis, and empiric antibiotic treatment with intravenous cefepime is begun. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's pneumonia?
hint: Postoperative care should include measures to prevent postoperative pulmonary complications.
learning_objective: Choose the most effective measure to prevent postoperative pneumonia.

answers.explanation_why:
Incentive spirometry and deep breathing exercises can maintain and improve lung function after surgery by keeping alveoli open, thereby decreasing the risk of atelectasis and pneumonia. Although some studies have shown a limited effect, these measures are still recommended following thoracic and upper abdominal surgery because they are safe and cost-effective. Multiple factors increase the postoperative risk of pneumonia, such as restricted thoracic and abdominal movement due to pain and intubation-related changes in ventilation (e.g., mechanical compression, impaired surfactant functioning). Further strategies to promote lung expansion include early mobilization and adequate postoperative pain control.

Preoperative measures to reduce pulmonary complications include smoking cessation (preferably ≥ 8 weeks before surgery), oral care (e.g., dental consult, improved oral hygiene), and treatment optimization for chronic lung diseases (e.g., asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).

Rapid sequence induction (RSI) is indicated in patients at high risk for pulmonary aspiration. While aspiration can cause pneumonia, this patient has no obvious risk factors for aspiration such as emergency surgery, severe GERD, anatomical defects of the gastrointestinal tract (e.g., hiatal hernia), or loss of protective airway reflexes.

Adequate breathing for this patient may be limited by postoperative pain following open abdominal surgery. Analgesics, including with opioids if needed, play an important role in ensuring sufficient breathing following such procedures to prevent postoperative atelectasis and/or pneumonia. A reduction in opioid consumption would not be indicated. Minimizing opioid administration would help prevent postoperative ileus, but this patient currently has no signs or symptoms of ileus.

For patients undergoing an open procedure, a single injection of antibiotics is usually administered directly before the procedure. Perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis reduces the incidence of postoperative surgical site infections. However, this single dose would not have prevented the development of postoperative pneumonia in this patient.

Good preoperative oral hygiene (e.g., brushing teeth twice daily, flossing daily, regular professional dental cleanings) reduces oral bacteria, lowering the risk of postoperative pneumonia. However, preoperative chlorhexidine mouthwash is only recommended for patients undergoing cardiac surgery.

question_text: A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and vomiting for 3 hours. She has had previous episodes of abdominal pain that lasted for 10–15 minutes and resolved with antacids. She lives with her daughter and grandchildren. She divorced her husband last year. She is alert and oriented. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 134/min, and blood pressure is 101/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is rigid and diffusely tender. Guarding and rebound tenderness are present. Rectal examination shows a collapsed rectum. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun, and a CT scan of the abdomen shows intestinal perforation. The surgeon discusses the need for emergency exploratory laparotomy with the patient, and she agrees to it. Written informed consent is obtained. While in the holding area awaiting transport to the operating room, she calls for the surgeon and informs him that she no longer wants the surgery. He explains the risks of not performing the surgery to her, and she indicates that she understands and is adamant about not proceeding with surgery. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and vomiting for 3 hours. She has had previous episodes of abdominal pain that lasted for 10–15 minutes and resolved with antacids. She lives with her daughter and grandchildren. She divorced her husband last year. She is alert and oriented. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 134/min, and blood pressure is 101/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is rigid and diffusely tender. Guarding and rebound tenderness are present. Rectal examination shows a collapsed rectum. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun, and a CT scan of the abdomen shows intestinal perforation. The surgeon discusses the need for emergency exploratory laparotomy with the patient, and she agrees to it. Written informed consent is obtained. While in the holding area awaiting transport to the operating room, she calls for the surgeon and informs him that she no longer wants the surgery. He explains the risks of not performing the surgery to her, and she indicates that she understands and is adamant about not proceeding with surgery. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient appears to have decision-making capacity and has made a treatment decision.
learning_objective: Recognize a patient's right to informed refusal of treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Consulting the hospital ethics committee would be appropriate if the patient were legally incompetent and there were a conflict among family members regarding the appropriate next step in the management of the patient. Since this patient appears to understand the risks of refusing the surgery, makes a clear statement, and has decision-making capacity, the hospital ethics committee does not need to be consulted.

Canceling the surgery is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient. The patient initially gave informed consent for the procedure, meaning that the physician already determined she had decision-making capacity, she was given sufficient information by the physician, and she made a voluntary decision. Although this decision was documented correctly, the patient's wishes (even verbally expressed) overrule her prior consent at any time before and even during the procedure, assuming the requirements for informed consent, or rather informed refusal, are still present.

Continuing with emergency life-saving surgery would be appropriate in a patient who was not capable of making an informed decision (e.g., in a situation requiring implied consent). This patient, however, shows no signs of decreased decision-making capacity. Continuing the procedure at this time despite the patient's refusal would be illegal.

answers.content: Obtain consent from the patient's daughter
answers.explanation_why: Consent from a person other than the patient must be obtained if the patient does not have legal competence or decision-making capacity. In these cases, a surrogate decision-maker must decide instead of the patient. This patient's daughter would be her surrogate if the patient were to become incompetent and had no advance directive. However, at this time, based on her understanding and communication of a clear decision, the patient has decision-making capacity.

answers.content: Obtain consent from the patient's ex-husband
answers.explanation_why: In the absence of an advance directive, the following sequence determines the priority of surrogates: (1) spouse, (2) adult children, (3) parents, (4) adult siblings, and (5) other relatives or friends. Therefore, the patient's ex-husband, who is not her current spouse, would not be the surrogate. In addition, a surrogate decision-maker is only needed if the patient is incompetent, whereas this woman appears to understand the risks and benefits of the procedure and verbalizes a clear decision.

answers.content: Wait until the patient is unconscious, then proceed with surgery
answers.explanation_why: Life-saving emergency surgery can be performed without informed consent in unconscious patients (i.e., in the case of implied consent). However, this patient had decision-making capacity both on arrival and when she revoked informed consent. Waiting until the patient is unconscious and then proceeding with emergency surgery would be highly unethical.

question_text: A 69-year-old man is scheduled to undergo a total pancreatectomy in one month. He has a history of chronic pancreatitis, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and severe osteoarthritis in both knees. He is unable to climb the stairs because of knee pain and only walks indoors around his house. He has severe abdominal pain due to chronic pancreatitis but does not report any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes and consumed 4–6 beers daily for 25 years but quit smoking and alcohol consumption 5 years ago. Current medications include insulin, metoprolol, lisinopril, rosuvastatin, ibuprofen, and pregabalin. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination and a 12-lead ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for assessing this patient's perioperative cardiac risk?
content_preview: A 69-year-old man is scheduled to undergo a total pancreatectomy in one month. He has a history of chronic pancreatitis, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and severe osteoarthritis in both knees. He is unable to climb the stairs because of knee pain and only walks indoors around his house. He has severe abdominal pain due to chronic pancreatitis but does not report any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes and consumed 4–6 beers daily for 25 years but quit smoking and alcohol consumption 5 years ago. Current medications include insulin, metoprolol, lisinopril, rosuvastatin, ibuprofen, and pregabalin. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination and a 12-lead ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for assessing this patient's perioperative cardiac risk?
hint: The combination of high-risk surgery (major intraabdominal surgery) and multiple cardiovascular risk factors (insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia) indicates a high risk of myocardial infarction in the intra- and postoperative periods.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for preoperative cardiac risk assessment, and choose the most appropriate stress test.

answers.explanation_why: Ambulatory ECG monitoring is indicated when standard ECG fails to provide information about symptoms such as palpitations or unexplained syncope, but it is not used to assess preoperative cardiac risk. Additionally, this patient has no history of rhythm or conduction abnormalities.

The goal of preoperative cardiac stress testing (CST) is to identify patients who might require cardiac revascularization before nonemergent surgeries. Preoperative CST should be considered for a patient who has a high major adverse cardiac event risk and poor or unknown functional capacity. CST is performed using ECG or cardiac imaging (e.g., stress echocardiography, myocardial perfusion imaging). An exercise stress test can be performed if the patient is able to achieve ≥ 5 metabolic equivalents using the chosen exercise modality. For patients who are unable to do so, pharmacological stress testing (i.e., with adenosine, dipyridamole, regadenoson, or dobutamine) is the most appropriate option. If a stress test is abnormal, preoperative revascularization (percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting) can be considered to decrease the risk of major adverse cardiac events.

Nonstress echocardiography is not routinely indicated for the preoperative evaluation of patients undergoing noncardiac surgery, but it may be performed if there are specific indications for the test, such as heart failure, new onset (or exacerbation) of cardiac symptoms, or known valvular heart disease.

Coronary CT angiography (CCTA) is performed in patients who are symptomatic (with angina or angina equivalents) and have an intermediate to high pretest probability of coronary artery disease (CAD). Coronary angiography, regardless of whether performed noninvasively (with a CT scan) or invasively (using cardiac catheterization), should not be performed as the first step to assess perioperative cardiac risk in asymptomatic patients without known CAD.

answers.content: Serial troponin and natriuretic peptide measurement
answers.explanation_why: Serial troponin measurement is important when a patient is suspected to have an acute coronary syndrome (ACS) but plays no role in preoperative risk assessment for asymptomatic patients without evidence of ACS. While natriuretic peptide B is a biomarker that is increasingly being used to assess perioperative risk, its measurement is typically for patients known to have cardiovascular disease or suspected to have heart failure.

question_text:
A 67-year-old man comes to the physician for a preoperative visit. He has a scheduled tumor resection for adenocarcinoma of the colon in 1 week. He was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma in the colon during a recent hospitalization. Staging showed that the tumor had infiltrated into the visceral peritoneum and that there was no distant metastasis. He has had a decreased appetite and a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. He used to play tennis but stopped 3 months ago as he was having trouble keeping pace with the game. He has stable angina, mild intermittent asthma, and hypertension. He quit smoking last year but used to smoke 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 45 years. His current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, and an albuterol inhaler, which he last used 3 months ago. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 56.7 kg (125 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m^2. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 86/min and regular, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows hair thinning and loss of the subcutaneous fat in his cheeks. The thyroid gland is enlarged. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL

Leukocyte count
9000/mm^3

Serum

Na^+

134 mEq/L

K^+

3.9 mEq/L

Cl^-

98 mEq/L

HCO_3^-

24 mEq/L

Urea nitrogen
17 mg/dL

Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL

Glucose
95 mg/dL

Total protein
5.8 g/dL

Albumin
2.1 g/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in preoperative management?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician for a preoperative visit. He has a scheduled tumor resection for adenocarcinoma of the colon in 1 week. He was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma in the colon during a recent hospitalization. Staging showed that the tumor had infiltrated into the visceral peritoneum and that there was no distant metastasis. He has had a decreased appetite and a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. He used to play tennis but stopped 3 months ago as he was having trouble keeping pace with the game. He has stable angina, mild intermittent asthma, and hypertension. He quit smoking last year but used to smoke 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 45 years. His current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, and an albuterol inhaler, which he last used 3 months ago. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 56.7 kg (125 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 86/min and regular, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows hair thinning and loss of the subcutaneous fat in his cheeks. The thyroid gland is enlarged. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL Leukocyte count 9000/mm3 Serum Na+ 134 mEq/L K+ 3.9 mEq/L Cl- 98 mEq/L HCO3- 24 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 17 mg/dL Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL Glucose 95 mg/dL Total protein 5.8 g/dL Albumin 2.1 g/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in preoperative management?
hint: This patient's condition is associated with poorer postoperative outcomes including increased overall morbidity and mortality, longer hospital stays, increased risk of infection, delayed wound healing, and increased rate of ICU admissions.
learning_objective: Recognize malnutrition in a preoperative patient, and choose the most appropriate nutritional support.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary function testing (PFT) is routinely used in the preoperative evaluation of patients undergoing thoracic surgery or to help plan lung resection. It is also used to preoperatively evaluate patients undergoing nonthoracic procedures who have unexplained dyspnea, exercise intolerance, or lung disease (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma) with significantly impaired airflow or abnormal baseline level of respiratory function. This patient will undergo intraabdominal rather than thoracic surgery. Additionally, as he last used his rescue inhaler 3 months ago and his lung examination was normal, his asthma is controlled and he has no evidence of significantly impaired airflow, making PFT unnecessary.

Antianginal drugs such as metoprolol and other beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, and nitrates can have deleterious effects if stopped abruptly, including exacerbation of ischemic heart disease with worsened angina and even myocardial infarction. Patients on metoprolol should continue to take the agent in the perioperative period, either enterally or parenterally. On the day of the procedure, metoprolol and any other necessary medications can be safely taken with sips of water 2 hours prior to anesthesia.

24-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring can be useful in detecting transient ECG changes, such as those associated with episodes of palpitations. A preoperative ECG is recommended in patients with one or more of the Revised Cardiac Risk Indicators as well as one of the following risk factors: age > 65 years, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, peripheral vascular disease, or arrhythmias. Although a preoperative ECG is indicated in this patient, a single ECG is generally sufficient for preoperative assessments.

This patient has malnutrition, as indicated by low albumin and protein levels, a recent weight loss of > 7.5% body weight in 3 months, loss of subcutaneous fat, muscle wasting, enlargement of the thyroid gland (likely due to iodine deficiency), and reduced functional capacity. Because of the potential negative outcomes associated with malnutrition, all preoperative patients should be screened for appropriate nutritional status. Malnourished patients should receive nutritional support, which may be delivered either enterally or parenterally. Enteral feeding helps preserve the normal physiology and immune function of the digestive system and therefore should be preferred over parenteral nutritional support whenever possible. Oral feeding is not contraindicated in this patient so he would benefit from high-protein oral nutritional supplementation, which is recommended for malnourished patients with malignancy or wounds.

Other preoperative testing this patient may need includes a chest x-ray, since he is > 60 years of age, has a history of cardiac disease, and a recent history of significant cigarette use, as well as an ECG, because he is > 65 years old and has a history of ischemic heart disease.

answers.content: Measurement of free T4 and total T3
answers.explanation_why: Measuring free T4 and total T3 could help determine the functionality of the thyroid gland. Hyperthyroidism can also manifest with thyromegaly and weight loss. However, this patient's low albumin and protein suggest a different underlying cause of his weight loss. In addition, this patient does not have other symptoms of hyperthyroidism such as tachycardia, heat intolerance, diarrhea, or increased appetite. Lastly, if there was a concern for hyperthyroidism, the first-line test to evaluate thyroid function would be measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone, not free T4 and total T3.

Selective bowel decontamination is primarily used prior to liver transplant surgery, but can also be useful in decreasing the incidence of nosocomial pneumonia and mortality in intubated patients. Bowel decontamination is not a common practice for cases of colon resection. In addition, vancomycin is not a first-choice antibiotic for selective bowel decontamination as it is mainly used for gram-positive coverage or when MRSA is suspected. It is not used against gram-negative rods, which are common organisms in the GI tract.

This patient has multiple risk factors for postoperative complications, e.g., age > 60 years, a history of cardiac disease with significant smoking history, abnormal laboratory findings and exam findings (e.g., enlarged thyroid, loss of subcutaneous fat), and cancer. He needs appropriate preoperative evaluation and optimization prior to undergoing surgery.

question_text:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling 16 feet from a ladder. He has severe pain in both his legs and his right arm. He appears pale and diaphoretic. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min and weak, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He opens his eyes and withdraws in response to painful stimuli and makes incomprehensible sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. All extremities are cold, with 1+ pulses distally. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.29

PCO_2

33 mm Hg

PO_2

65 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

15 mEq/L

A CT scan shows displaced fractures of the pelvic ring, as well as fractures of both tibiae, the right distal radius, and right proximal humerus. The patient undergoes emergent open reduction and is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following best indicates inadequate fluid resuscitation?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling 16 feet from a ladder. He has severe pain in both his legs and his right arm. He appears pale and diaphoretic. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min and weak, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He opens his eyes and withdraws in response to painful stimuli and makes incomprehensible sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. All extremities are cold, with 1+ pulses distally. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.29 PCO2 33 mm Hg PO2 65 mm Hg HCO3- 15 mEq/L A CT scan shows displaced fractures of the pelvic ring, as well as fractures of both tibiae, the right distal radius, and right proximal humerus. The patient undergoes emergent open reduction and is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following best indicates inadequate fluid resuscitation?
hint: There are many ways that physicians monitor volume status, but some are more reliable than others in the absence of confounding medications or illnesses.
learning_objective: Recognize indicators of inadequate fluid resuscitation, and recall the expected urine output for adequate end-organ perfusion.

answers.explanation_why: High pulse pressure is usually caused by an increase in stroke volume (e.g., normal exercise, aortic regurgitation) or a decrease in arterial compliance (e.g., atherosclerosis) and would likely increase following fluid resuscitation. However, pulse pressure is an indicator of stroke volume and not a direct indicator of end-organ perfusion. Fluid resuscitation aims to achieve adequate end-organ perfusion, so a change in pulse pressure is not the best indicator to evaluate fluid resuscitation.

answers.content: Urine output of 25 mL in 3 hours
answers.explanation_why:
The goal of fluid resuscitation is to maintain adequate end-organ perfusion and to restore intravascular volume. Since renal blood flow (and therefore GFR) is highly sensitive to changes in blood pressure and intravascular volume, urine output can serve as a surrogate measure to determine if fluid resuscitation is adequate. Ideally, urine output in adults should be greater than 0.5 mL/kg/hr. Therefore, a 70-kg man should have a urine output of 35–70 mL/hr. A urine output of 25mL in 3 hours suggests that his kidneys are not receiving adequate blood flow and therefore that he has not received adequate fluid resuscitation.

With adequate fluid resuscitation, an increase in some of the other indices, such as pulse pressure and Glasgow coma scale, might occur before a change in urine output is apparent. However, these parameters are not specific indicators of end-organ perfusion. Other parameters, such as lactate and a base deficit, are more useful for determining the prognosis than for guiding fluid therapy.

Confusion, lethargy, and even coma can be seen in patients with severe shock. However, a low Glasgow coma score (GCS) following trauma may be caused by a number of factors, including hypotension, hypoxia, and intracranial hemorrhage. Therefore, the GCS should not be used as a guide for fluid therapy.

An increase in serum lactate (> 4 mEq/L) may indicate tissue hypoxia due to inadequate tissue perfusion. However, serum lactate levels are not used to determine whether fluid resuscitation is inadequate because, even after adequate fluid resuscitation and correction of tissue hypoperfusion, lactate levels may not reach normal levels (< 2 mEq/L) for a few hours. Lactate clearance may take even longer in critically ill patients as a result of a prolonged lactate half-life (due to hepatic and/or renal dysfunction) and/or increased glycolysis. In trauma patients, elevated lactate levels are associated with increased mortality and are used to evaluate the prognosis.

A prolonged capillary refill time (≥ 3 seconds) is seen as a result of peripheral vasoconstriction in patients with hypotension. However, capillary refill is not the most direct measure of organ perfusion and adequate volume resuscitation, as it can be affected by confounding factors (e.g., ambient temperature, lighting, physical exam techniques, peripheral artery disease, blood viscosity).

This patient has an increased base deficit (> 2 mEq/L), which indicates metabolic acidosis (most likely due to lactic acidosis from inadequate perfusion and fluid resuscitation). Normalization of the base deficit (< 2 mmol/L) following fluid resuscitation would suggest an improvement in tissue perfusion and a more favorable prognosis, not inadequate fluid resuscitation.

question_text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He has acute myeloid leukemia and is currently receiving chemotherapy. On arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and sluggish. There are multiple bruises over the face, trunk, and right upper and lower extremities. There is a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over his right cheek. He does not respond to any commands but does groan. Painful stimuli cause him to open his eyes and withdraw all extremities. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. There is tenderness to palpation over the left chest wall. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. There is swelling of the right elbow and wrist. The right lower extremity is shorter than the left lower extremity. There are 2 lacerations around 2 cm (0.8 in) each on the right leg. The right knee is swollen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He has acute myeloid leukemia and is currently receiving chemotherapy. On arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and sluggish. There are multiple bruises over the face, trunk, and right upper and lower extremities. There is a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over his right cheek. He does not respond to any commands but does groan. Painful stimuli cause him to open his eyes and withdraw all extremities. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. There is tenderness to palpation over the left chest wall. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. There is swelling of the right elbow and wrist. The right lower extremity is shorter than the left lower extremity. There are 2 lacerations around 2 cm (0.8 in) each on the right leg. The right knee is swollen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8 (groans = 2; opens eyes to pain = 2; withdraws extremities to pain = 4).
learning_objective: Recognize the need for airway protection in a patient with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 8, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: The patient does have abdominal tenderness and will require some form of assessment for intraabdominal bleeding such as a FAST scan, but only after implementing a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

A pelvic binder would address critical blood loss and help stabilize potential pelvic fractures, but it would not address the primary concern as dictated by the ABCDE approach to treating trauma patients.

An intercostal chest tube is indicated for treating tension pneumothorax (TP). The patient has decreased breath sounds at the right lung base, a finding associated with TP, but does not show other signs like tachypnea, tracheal deviation away from the affected lung, or jugular venous distention, making TP an unlikely diagnosis. The first priority for this patient with a GCS score of 8 is another very critical measure of the ATLS-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

answers.content: CT scan of the head and neck
answers.explanation_why: The patient will require imaging of the head to assess intracranial bleeding and other damage to the head and neck area. Imaging of the neck is especially important for assessment of cervical spine integrity. However, head and neck imaging can take place only after implementing a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

This patient will need evaluation of his extremities for bone and soft tissue damage, but only after implementation of a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

As a general rule, patients with a GCS score of 8 or below as a result of traumatic brain injury require intubation and mechanical ventilation to protect the airway and ensure adequate ventilation. Such patients are at risk of airway obstruction via aspiration because they lack a gag reflex. They are also at risk of hypoxia from poor ventilation because brainstem damage can decrease the respiratory drive.

question_text:
Twelve hours after undergoing a femoral artery embolectomy, an 84-year-old man is found unconscious on the floor by his hospital bed. He had received a patient-controlled analgesia pump after surgery. He underwent 2 coronary bypass surgeries 2 and 6 years ago. He has coronary artery disease, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications include metoprolol, atorvastatin, lisinopril, sublingual nitrate, and insulin. He appears pale. His temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 88/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. The patient does not respond to commands and withdraws his extremities to pain. Examination shows cold, clammy skin and jugular venous distention. There is ecchymosis on the right temple and maxilla. There is a surgical incision over the right thigh that shows no erythema or discharge. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A central venous catheter is placed and hemodynamic monitoring shows:

Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)
1600 dynes.sec/cm^5 (N = 900–1400)

Right atrial pressure

13 mm Hg (N = 3–8)

Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)

4 mm Hg (N = 5–16)

Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: Twelve hours after undergoing a femoral artery embolectomy, an 84-year-old man is found unconscious on the floor by his hospital bed. He had received a patient-controlled analgesia pump after surgery. He underwent 2 coronary bypass surgeries 2 and 6 years ago. He has coronary artery disease, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications include metoprolol, atorvastatin, lisinopril, sublingual nitrate, and insulin. He appears pale. His temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 88/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. The patient does not respond to commands and withdraws his extremities to pain. Examination shows cold, clammy skin and jugular venous distention. There is ecchymosis on the right temple and maxilla. There is a surgical incision over the right thigh that shows no erythema or discharge. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A central venous catheter is placed and hemodynamic monitoring shows: Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) 1600 dynes.sec/cm5 (N = 900–1400) Right atrial pressure 13 mm Hg (N = 3–8) Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) 4 mm Hg (N = 5–16) Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with features of shock: tachycardia, hypotension, and clinical signs of end-organ hypoperfusion (altered consciousness, cold and clammy skin). This patient's hemodynamic parameters help to identify the most likely type of shock.
learning_objective: Recognize features of shock, and recall the diagnostic finding of obstructive shock due to pulmonary embolism.

answers.content: Decreased hematocrit on complete blood count
answers.explanation_why:
Decreased hematocrit on complete blood count can be seen in hemorrhagic shock. This patient recently underwent surgery and sustained a fall, both of which could have led to bleeding. Additionally, patients with hemorrhagic shock typically present with increased SVR and decreased PCWP. However, increased right atrial pressure and jugular venous distension are not expected in hemorrhagic shock.

Note that in acute hemorrhage, hematocrit and hemoglobin may initially be normal as loss of plasma and blood cells occur in proportion; hematocrit and hemoglobin decrease following fluid shifting.

answers.content: Filling defect of a pulmonary artery on CT pulmonary angiography
answers.explanation_why: A filling defect of a pulmonary artery on CT pulmonary angiography indicates pulmonary embolism (PE). Massive PE can cause major obstruction of the pulmonary vasculature, resulting in increased right heart pressures and features of right heart failure, like jugular venous distension. Obstruction of the pulmonary vessels leads to a decreased right heart output, resulting in normal or mildly decreased PCWP and decreased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, which leads to decreased cardiac output and, consequently, obstructive shock. SVR increases to compensate for the decrease in cardiac output.

answers.content: ST-segment elevations in leads V1 through V6
answers.explanation_why: Cardiogenic shock due to ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is an important differential diagnosis in this patient with a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes mellitus. Cardiogenic shock typically manifests with increased SVR and increased right atrial pressure and jugular venous distension can be seen if there is right ventricular failure. However, given the ECG leads affected (V_1 through V_6), features of left ventricular failure (e.g., pulmonary edema, increased PCWP) would be expected.

answers.content: Elevated serum procalcitonin and interleukin-6 levels
answers.explanation_why: Elevated serum procalcitonin and interleukin-6 levels would indicate septic shock, which is an unlikely diagnosis in a patient without findings suggestive of an infectious process (e.g., fever). Additionally, patients with septic shock typically have decreased SVR. Finally, increased right atrial pressure and jugular venous distension are not expected.

answers.content: Improved mental status after naloxone administration
answers.explanation_why: Improved mental status after naloxone administration suggests opioid overdose, which should be considered since the patient was receiving an opiate through a patient-controlled analgesia device. Although opioid toxicity manifests with features that are also present here (e.g., altered mental status, hypotension), bradypnea or hypopnea would be far more likely than tachypnea. Furthermore, the hemodynamic findings seen here are not consistent with opioid overdose and suggest a different etiology.

question_text: A 32-year-old man is brought to a small community health center after being stabbed in the abdomen during an altercation. The physician is working alone. The patient has shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and bleeding. He is alert and active. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 89/61 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm wound at the right subcostal region with active bleeding. The knife is still in the wound. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to a small community health center after being stabbed in the abdomen during an altercation. The physician is working alone. The patient has shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and bleeding. He is alert and active. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 89/61 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm wound at the right subcostal region with active bleeding. The knife is still in the wound. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: This hemodynamically unstable patient presents to a small community health center after a penetrating abdominal trauma that requires immediate surgery.
learning_objective: Recognize penetrating abdominal trauma with hemodynamic instability, and choose the most appropriate initial action.

answers.explanation_why: Bilateral tube thoracostomy is indicated in a patient with pneumothorax, pleural effusion, or intrathoracic hemorrhage. These conditions are associated with absent or decreased breath sounds, whereas this patient's lungs are clear to auscultation. Additionally, the stab wound is below the costal margin and therefore less likely to injure the lungs.

answers.content: Remove the knife carefully and apply pressure to the wound
answers.explanation_why: The knife might be acting as a tamponade on the wound, thereby concealing vascular damage and preventing further hemorrhage. Although emergency surgery is indicated, impaled foreign bodies should be removed under direct visualization in an operating room where bleeding can be controlled.

answers.content: Type and cross for transfusion of packed red blood cells
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient shows signs of active bleeding and will likely need blood transfusions, a type and cross is a blood test that takes time and would not address his primary problem of intraabdominal bleeding from a stab wound.

Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is the preferred method of endotracheal intubation in emergency settings because it obviates the need for bag valve mask ventilation and decreases the risk of vomiting and aspiration in patients who have not fasted. Although RSI may be indicated in this patient prior to undergoing surgery, immediate RSI is not indicated as he is conscious, has a patent airway, and is not at impending risk of respiratory failure or aspiration.

answers.content: Arrange for transport to the nearest trauma center
answers.explanation_why: In this patient with penetrating abdominal trauma, hypotension and tachycardia suggest intraabdominal hemorrhage, which needs to be controlled immediately. Although other lifesaving measures (i.e., fluid resuscitation) should also be conducted as soon as possible and might be done in parallel if more personnel were present, this physician is working alone. To prevent the patient from potentially bleeding to death, immediate transfer to an operating room is indicated. Establishing IV access and setting up fluids may be conducted after arranging transport or on the way to a trauma center. Once the patient is transferred, an exploratory laparotomy should be performed.
