question_text: One day after undergoing total knee replacement for advanced degenerative osteoarthritis, a 66-year-old man has progressive lower abdominal pain. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia and the patient was temporarily catheterized for perioperative fluid balance. Several hours after the surgery, the patient began to have decreasing voiding volumes, nausea, and progressive, dull lower abdominal pain. Medical history is remarkable for Sjögren syndrome. He does not smoke and drinks one to two beers on the weekends. Current medications include pilocarpine eye drops. He appears uncomfortable and is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a pelvic mass extending to the umbilicus. It is dull on percussion and diffusely tender to palpation. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9000/mm^3, and platelet count is 230,000/mm^3. An attempt to recatheterize the patient transurethrally is unsuccessful. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?
content_preview: One day after undergoing total knee replacement for advanced degenerative osteoarthritis, a 66-year-old man has progressive lower abdominal pain. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia and the patient was temporarily catheterized for perioperative fluid balance. Several hours after the surgery, the patient began to have decreasing voiding volumes, nausea, and progressive, dull lower abdominal pain. Medical history is remarkable for Sjögren syndrome. He does not smoke and drinks one to two beers on the weekends. Current medications include pilocarpine eye drops. He appears uncomfortable and is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a pelvic mass extending to the umbilicus. It is dull on percussion and diffusely tender to palpation. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9000/mm3, and platelet count is 230,000/mm3. An attempt to recatheterize the patient transurethrally is unsuccessful. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?
hint: This patient has postoperative oliguria, lower abdominal pain, and a palpable pelvic mass that is dull on percussion, suggesting bladder distention. In combination, these findings indicate acute urinary retention (AUR).
learning_objective: Recognize benign prostatic hyperplasia as a cause of acute urinary retention.

answers.explanation_why:
Several risk factors can contribute to postoperative AUR, including male sex, age > 50 years, joint arthroplasty, and preexisting urinary tract obstruction such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is the most common cause of bladder outflow obstruction and AUR in older men. An acute inability to micturate can be the initial presentation of BPH.

Since transurethral catheterization was not successful, a suprapubic catheter should be placed for immediate relief of the distended bladder. Following this, the patient should undergo a trial of voiding without a catheter. Furthermore, the outflow obstruction should be evaluated with a uroflowmetry test to quantify the obstruction, and the suitability for treatment options, e.g., with alpha-1 blockers, should be discussed.

A number of drugs that act on the autonomic system can cause AUR by either decreasing detrusor activity (parasympatholytic agents) or increasing urethral sphincter tone (sympathomimetic agents). Pilocarpine is, however, a direct parasympathomimetic agent that would increase detrusor activity, which facilitates bladder emptying. This patient also takes pilocarpine intraocularly, which makes it highly unlikely that the systemic concentration of the drug would be high enough to have any effect on the bladder.

Acute prostatitis is usually caused by a bacterial infection of the urinary tract and may also manifest with AUR. While this patient's history of indwelling catheterization puts him at higher risk for urinary tract infections, acute bacterial prostatitis usually manifests with spiking fevers, chills, and perineal pain. The absence of fever and a normal leukocyte count make acute prostatitis unlikely.

Urethral stricture is a possible cause of AUR. Iatrogenic manipulation (e.g., injury related to transurethral insertion of an oversized endoscope or catheter placement) is the most common etiology of urethral stricture. While this patient was catheterized transurethrally during surgery, it takes much longer than several hours for scar tissue of a urethral stricture to form. Recurrent urethritis may also cause urethral stricture. Because this patient has no history of previous surgeries requiring catheterization or recurrent urethral infections, urethral stricture is an unlikely diagnosis.

Neurogenic lower urinary tract dysfunction (NLUTD) may manifest with AUR and is a common cause of bladder outflow obstruction, especially in young men and women. It results from injury to the central nervous system (e.g., multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, stroke) or the peripheral nerves that supply the bladder (e.g., diabetic neuropathy). Postoperative NLUTD, however, is usually only seen following spinal anesthesia and abdominopelvic surgeries, either of which can cause neural damage resulting in impaired autonomic bladder control; NLUTD is highly unlikely to occur as a sequela of total knee replacement. In addition, an outflow obstruction due to NLUTD would be correctable with recatheterization, which was unsuccessful in this patient.

question_text: A 19-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department 30 minutes after diving head-first into a shallow pool of water from a cliff. He was placed on a spinal board and a rigid cervical collar was applied by the emergency medical technicians. On arrival, he is unconscious and withdraws all extremities to pain. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 102/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the forehead. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a step-off palpated over the cervical spine. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 19-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department 30 minutes after diving head-first into a shallow pool of water from a cliff. He was placed on a spinal board and a rigid cervical collar was applied by the emergency medical technicians. On arrival, he is unconscious and withdraws all extremities to pain. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 102/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the forehead. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a step-off palpated over the cervical spine. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has likely sustained a cervical spine injury that is compromising his respiratory function.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for a patient with suspected cervical spine injury and respiratory insufficiency.

answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the spine is an appropriate diagnostic test for the management of suspected cervical injuries, but it should only be done after the patient has been stabilized. Although the patient's mechanism of injury and physical examination are both consistent with a cervical fracture, the patient's respiratory status is compromised (he is unconscious and his respiratory rate is 8/min). Delaying airway management in favor of imaging could be devastating if the patient were to decompensate inside the CT scanner.

An x-ray of the cervical spine can be considered in the workup of a trauma patient with a suspected cervical spine injury. However, imaging should only be performed after the airway has been secured if there is evidence of respiratory compromise (such as this patient's altered mental status and respiratory rate of 8/min). Moreover, a CT scan would usually be preferable in adult trauma patients with suspected cervical spine injury given its higher sensitivity.

answers.content: CT of the brain and spine
answers.explanation_why: This patient has a mechanism of injury and physical examination findings that are consistent with a cervical spine fracture. Given the forehead laceration and the patient's altered mental status, he is also at high risk of intracranial hemorrhage, and a CT scan of both the brain and spine would be helpful in forming a diagnosis. However, the patient's airway is compromised and he shows signs of respiratory insufficiency (respiratory rate of 8/min). Delaying airway management in favor of imaging could be devastating if the patient were to decompensate inside the CT scanner.

This patient's mechanism of injury and physical examination are both consistent with a cervical fracture that is complicated by altered mental status with respiratory insufficiency (respiratory rate of 8/min). Rapid sequence intubation is vital to secure the patient's airway and allow for proper management of his cervical injury. Cervical fractures may lead to immediate or delayed cervical spinal cord compression and/or phrenic nerve paralysis and subsequent respiratory failure. Although an oxygen saturation of 96% may seem reassuring, hypercapnic respiratory failure may manifest with normal pulse oximetry. Delaying intubation in favor of imaging could lead to respiratory arrest, seizure, and death.

See “Primary trauma survey”.

Laryngeal mask airway devices are not the recommended method of airway management in an unconscious patient with impaired respiratory status, especially in a trauma setting, where a laryngeal mask might exacerbate occult esophageal injury. They may be used in the case of failed intubation due to a difficult airway, but intubation has not yet been attempted.

Rectal tone assessment is performed during the Disability or Exposure portions of the primary trauma survey. As such, it should not be performed until after the Airway, Breathing, and Circulation portions of the primary survey have been completed, especially in a patient who is unconscious and has a respiratory rate of 8/min.

An MRI of the spine may be used for the diagnosis of traumatic spinal cord injury as well as presurgical planning. However, this patient's respiratory status is compromised (he is unconscious and his respiratory rate is 8/min). Delaying airway management in favor of imaging could be devastating if the patient were to decompensate inside the MRI scanner. Moreover, a CT scan would be preferable in most trauma patients, given its much shorter duration.

question_text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of painful swelling of the right hand. There is no associated recent trauma. Physical examination shows a 3 × 3 cm area of induration that is fluctuant and warm to the touch, consistent with an abscess. The patient consents to incision and drainage of the abscess in the emergency department. Following evaluation of the patient's allergy status, a local anesthetic drug of the amide group with a particularly long duration of action is administered via subcutaneous infiltration. Which of the following local anesthetics was most likely administered?
content_preview: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of painful swelling of the right hand. There is no associated recent trauma. Physical examination shows a 3 × 3 cm area of induration that is fluctuant and warm to the touch, consistent with an abscess. The patient consents to incision and drainage of the abscess in the emergency department. Following evaluation of the patient's allergy status, a local anesthetic drug of the amide group with a particularly long duration of action is administered via subcutaneous infiltration. Which of the following local anesthetics was most likely administered?
hint: Anesthetic choice depends on several factors, including the duration of action required for the procedure, patient allergies, and the need for hemostasis. Many institutions use the same local anesthetic for most procedures, regardless of the duration of analgesia. However, this question asks specifically for a local anesthetic of the amide group that provides the longest duration of analgesia.
learning_objective: Recall the characteristics of amide local anesthetics.

answers.explanation_why: Bupivacaine is a long-acting, amide-type local anesthetic with an onset of ∼ 10 minutes and duration of action of 4–8 hours. Bupivacaine is commonly used for local infiltration if prolonged anesthesia or extended pain relief is required. Epinephrine is frequently combined with local anesthetics to decrease bleeding associated with procedures and to increase the duration of action of anesthesia.

Chloroprocaine is a short-acting, local anesthetic of the ester group with an onset of 6–12 minutes and duration of action of < 60 minutes. A different local anesthetic provides a longer duration of analgesia.

Procaine is a short-acting, local anesthetic of the ester group with an onset of approx. 5 minutes and duration of action of < 90 minutes. A different local anesthetic provides a longer duration of analgesia.

Lidocaine is an amide-type local anesthetic with rapid onset and intermediate duration of action of 50–120 minutes. It is the most commonly used local anesthetic; however, a different local anesthetic provides a longer duration of analgesia.
Mepivacaine is an amide-type local anesthetic with rapid onset and intermediate duration of action of 2–2.5 hours. A different local anesthetic provides a longer duration of analgesia.

Tetracaine is an intermediate to long-acting local anesthetic with rapid onset and a duration of action of 2–6 hours. However, it is an anesthetic of the ester group, not the amide group. In addition, a different local anesthetic provides a longer duration of analgesia.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a preoperative evaluation prior to an elective laparoscopic umbilical hernia repair. She feels well, but reports shortness of breath on mild exertion. She had a myocardial infarction 2 years ago and underwent placement of a stent in her left anterior descending artery. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, carvedilol, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 81 kg (176.4 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Pulmonary examination shows scattered crackles bilaterally. There is jugular venous distension. Abdominal examination shows a large umbilical hernia; cough impulse is present. ECG shows sinus rhythm and 2 to 3 premature atrial contractions per minute. Chest x-ray shows widened intercostal spaces and mild cardiomegaly. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications in this patient?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a preoperative evaluation prior to an elective laparoscopic umbilical hernia repair. She feels well, but reports shortness of breath on mild exertion. She had a myocardial infarction 2 years ago and underwent placement of a stent in her left anterior descending artery. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, carvedilol, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 81 kg (176.4 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Pulmonary examination shows scattered crackles bilaterally. There is jugular venous distension. Abdominal examination shows a large umbilical hernia; cough impulse is present. ECG shows sinus rhythm and 2 to 3 premature atrial contractions per minute. Chest x-ray shows widened intercostal spaces and mild cardiomegaly. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications in this patient?
hint: This patient's shortness of breath on mild exertion, crackles on auscultation, and cardiomegaly on chest x-ray, in combination with a history of ischemic heart disease, suggest congestive heart failure (CHF).
learning_objective: Recognize signs of congestive heart failure, and recall its perioperative risks.

answers.explanation_why: Although metabolic syndrome, which this patient most likely has (indicated by the patient's diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and obesity), increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, it is not an independent risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications according to the revised cardiac risk index. Diabetes mellitus alone is considered a risk factor but only if the patient already requires treatment with insulin, which is not the case here.

The patient's age is important to consider when planning surgery because old age is associated with an increased prevalence of conditions that increase the risk of perioperative cardiac complications (e.g., cardiovascular disease, cerebrovascular disease, diabetes mellitus). According to the Goldman risk index, patients ≥ 70 years of age are considered to be at increased risk of cardiac complications; this patient is 62 years of age. Furthermore, according to the revised cardiac risk index (the index most commonly used for perioperative cardiac risk assessment), age alone is not considered an independent risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications.

Jugular venous distention is a manifestation of this patient's CHF and a significant preoperative risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications. This patient's CHF and ischemic heart disease meet two of the criteria of the revised cardiac risk index (RCRI), putting her at increased risk of a perioperative cardiac event (e.g., acute myocardial infarction, cardiac arrest). Before undergoing surgery, this patient should be treated for CHF and undergo further cardiologic evaluation with a cardiac stress test.
answers.explanation_but: The Goldman risk index, developed in 1977, is no longer the preferred tool for assessing cardiac risk. It includes the presence of heart failure signs (JVD, S3 gallop) as the strongest risk factor for cardiac complications. RCRI (the updated version of the Goldman risk index) is now the most commonly used tool to assess perioperative cardiac risk.

answers.explanation_why: A history of smoking increases the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. Therefore, smoking cessation 8 weeks prior to surgery should be encouraged and perioperative pulmonary assessment should be considered. However, smoking is not an independent risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications according to the revised cardiac risk index.

Although premature atrial contractions (PACs) can indicate an underlying heart disease they are also commonly found in healthy individuals without heart disease. Therefore, the Goldman risk index includes all arrhythmias as risk factors for perioperative cardiac complications except for premature atrial contractions. In the revised cardiac risk index (the index most commonly used for perioperative cardiac risk assessment), arrhythmias are no longer considered independent risk factors for perioperative cardiac complications.

question_text:
A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of cough productive of yellowish sputum. He has had fever, chills, and worsening shortness of breath during this time. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. His current medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, and metoprolol. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He appears in mild distress. He has rales over the left lower lung field. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Leukocyte count is 15,000/mm^3 (87% segmented neutrophils). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.44

pO_2

68 mm Hg

pCO_2

28 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

24 mEq/L

O_2 saturation
91%

An x-ray of the chest shows a consolidation in the left lower lobe. Asking the patient to lie down in the left lateral decubitus position would most likely result in which of the following?

His current medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, and metoprolol. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He appears in mild distress. He has rales over the left lower lung field. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Leukocyte count is 15,000/mm3 (87% segmented neutrophils). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.44 pO2 68 mm Hg pCO2 28 mm Hg HCO3- 24 mEq/L O2 saturation 91% An x-ray of the chest shows a consolidation in the left lower lobe. Asking the patient to lie down in the left lateral decubitus position would most likely result in which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with clinical features of pneumonia, which impairs ventilation in the affected pulmonary tissue. The dependent regions of the lung are better perfused than the nondependent regions as gravity pulls the blood downward.
learning_objective: Recall the effects of body positioning on the A-a gradient in pneumonia.

answers.explanation_why: In the lateral decubitus position, the dependent lung is better perfused due to the effect of gravity. Putting this patient in the left lateral decubitus position will therefore increase the perfusion of the left, diseased lung, not of the right, healthy lung.

The perfusion of the nonventilated, consolidated alveoli in pneumonia causes a decreased ventilation-perfusion ratio that results in hypoxemia. Placing the patient in the left decubitus position would actually worsen hypoxemia as more blood passes through the nonventilated portion of the lung and less blood passes through the right, healthy lung. Additionally, the healthy lung will be ventilated less, further contributing to a worsening of hypoxemia.

This patient's arterial blood gas analysis shows hypocapnia, as evidenced by the pCO_2 of 28 mm Hg. In general, the dependent lung is better ventilated and perfused than the nondependent lung. Placing this patient with left lobar pneumonia in the left lateral decubitus position will increase ventilation and perfusion of the diseased lung. As there is no CO_2 and O_2 exchange at the sites of alveolar consolidation, there will be more CO_2 retention, resulting in an improvement of the hypocapnia (but a worsening of the hypoxia) in this patient.

answers.content: Decreased ventilation of the left lung
answers.explanation_why: Dependent portions of a healthy lung are better ventilated than the nondependent portions. This patient with pneumonia affecting the left lower lobe has consolidation on x-ray, which indicates the presence of fluid in the alveoli that prevents them from participating in ventilation. However, putting this patient in the left lateral decubitus position will still result in increased ventilation of the unaffected upper lobe of the diseased lung.

The alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) is the difference between the partial pressure of O_2 within the alveoli and that within the arterial blood. An increased A-a gradient indicates a ventilation/perfusion mismatch (V/Q mismatch) resulting in hypoxia. In pneumonia, ventilation decreases in the consolidated region of the lung due to alveolar inflammation (↓ V). In a lateral decubitus position, the dependent lung is better perfused (↑ Q) and ventilated than the nondependent regions. Placing this patient with left-sided pneumonia in the left lateral decubitus position will increase perfusion of the nonventilated alveoli, worsening the V/Q mismatch and increasing the A-a gradient.

Therefore, in patients with unilateral pneumonia with hypoxia, positioning the body with the healthy lung in the dependent position (“good lung down”) improves arterial oxygenation by increasing both its ventilation and perfusion.

question_text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with second- and third-degree burns covering 30% of the surface area of his body. He is alert and active. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 12 L/min by nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Intravenous fluids, intravenous and topical antibiotics, and intravenous pain medications are administered in the intensive care unit. Seventy-four hours later, the patient develops respiratory distress. Respirations are 30/min. There is inspiratory stridor. The patient requires rapid sequence intubation. Administration of succinylcholine during intubation would most likely result in which of the following complications in this patient?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with second- and third-degree burns covering 30% of the surface area of his body. He is alert and active. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 12 L/min by nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Intravenous fluids, intravenous and topical antibiotics, and intravenous pain medications are administered in the intensive care unit. Seventy-four hours later, the patient develops respiratory distress. Respirations are 30/min. There is inspiratory stridor. The patient requires rapid sequence intubation. Administration of succinylcholine during intubation would most likely result in which of the following complications in this patient?
hint: Administration of succinylcholine to a patient with severe burn injury after 72 hours significantly increases the risk of developing a certain complication.
learning_objective: Recall the complications of succinylcholine in burn patients.

answers.explanation_why: Prolonged administration of non-depolarizing paralytics (e.g., pancuronium) increases the risk of critical illness myopathy in critically ill and chronically immobilized patients (e.g., ICU patients who receive nondepolarizing muscle relaxants for a prolonged period of time to facilitate mechanical ventilation). Succinylcholine administration is not associated with an increased risk of critical illness myopathy.

Malignant hyperthermia is a rare complication of succinylcholine administration that typically occurs in patients with a predisposing genetic mutation. This patient does not have any personal history or family history of adverse reactions to anesthetics, so malignant hyperthermia is very unlikely. Malignant hyperthermia would present with tachycardia, muscle rigidity, and increased end-tidal CO_2 shortly after succinylcholine administration, followed by fever.

Some non-depolarizing paralytics (e.g., mivacurium) can induce the release of histamine, which can cause bronchospasm, especially at higher doses. Although bronchospasm is rarely reported after succinylcholine administration, another complication is much more likely to be seen in this patient with severe burn injuries.

Both cell lysis from the burn injury and the administration of succinylcholine can cause hyperkalemia, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmia. The post-junctional membrane depolarization induced by succinylcholine results in efflux of K^+ from muscle cells. The risk of hyperkalemia is significantly increased when succinylcholine is administered to patients with other risk factors for hyperkalemia (e.g., burns, trauma, kidney failure). Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers, such as rocuronium, are used to facilitate intubation under these circumstances to avoid hyperkalemia.

Respiratory depression is a complication of long-acting paralytic agents (e.g., pancuronium). Succinylcholine is typically rapidly metabolized and lasts < 10 minutes, so there is little risk of apnea. Some rare genetic mutations (e.g., congenital deficiency of plasma cholinesterase) can prolong succinylcholine's duration of action up to several hours. However, this patient has no history that would suggest such a mutation.

question_text: Two days after an uncomplicated laparoscopic abdominal hernia repair, a 46-year-old man is evaluated for palpitations. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a ventricular septal defect that closed spontaneously as a child. His father has coronary artery disease. Prior to admission, his only medications were hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. He currently also takes hydromorphone/acetaminophen for mild postoperative pain. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min and irregular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 139/85 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a normal S_1 and S_2 without murmurs and clear lung fields. The abdominal incisions are clean, dry, and intact. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the lower quadrants. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ECG findings?
content_preview: Two days after an uncomplicated laparoscopic abdominal hernia repair, a 46-year-old man is evaluated for palpitations. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a ventricular septal defect that closed spontaneously as a child. His father has coronary artery disease. Prior to admission, his only medications were hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. He currently also takes hydromorphone/acetaminophen for mild postoperative pain. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min and irregular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 139/85 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a normal S1 and S2 without murmurs and clear lung fields. The abdominal incisions are clean, dry, and intact. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the lower quadrants. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ECG findings?
hint: The ECG shows premature ventricular contractions (PVC) in bigeminy.
learning_objective: Recognize hypokalemia as a cause of postoperative arrhythmias.

answers.explanation_why:
Postoperative arrhythmia (e.g., PVCs) is a common finding following cardiac and noncardiac surgery. The underlying pathophysiology is often complex but contributing factors may include high levels of catecholamines (endogenously due to the perioperative stress state; exogenous in the case of cardiovascular support), electrolyte or acid-base imbalances (e.g., hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia), reduced ventilation (leading to hypoxia and/or hypercarbia), and certain drugs. This patient takes a thiazide diuretic (hydrochlorothiazide), which is associated with an increased risk of hypokalemia. In cardiac cells, hypokalemia inhibits cardiac Na-K ATPase and causes prolonged ventricular repolarization, which predisposes to arrhythmias.

Most patients with PVCs are asymptomatic and treatment (e.g., with antiarrhythmics or catheter ablation) is only required if PVCs are frequent or significantly symptomatic.

An accessory pathway in the heart is seen in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, a possible cause of arrhythmia. However, typical ECG findings in WPW syndrome include a shortened PR interval and a "slurred" upstroke in the QRS complex known as a delta wave, neither of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, WPW syndrome is a congenital defect that most commonly manifests during childhood or adolescence and would therefore be unlikely in a 46-year-old patient without a prior history of arrhythmias.

images.title: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Regular sinus rhythm
– Rate 68/min
– Normal axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Short PR interval (112 ms)
– Wide QRS complexes (126 ms) with delta waves (the slurred initial portion of the QRS complex; zoom box)A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. If seen in asymptomatic patients with no evidence of arrhythmia, this constellation of findings is referred to as the "WPW pattern”.

answers.explanation_why: While certain drugs that are administered in the perioperative period may trigger arrhythmias (e.g., antibiotics, antihistamines), hydromorphone is not a common cause.

Acute myocardial ischemia is a possible cause of postoperative arrhythmia (e.g., PVCs). While this patient has cardiovascular risk factors, including obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a family history of coronary artery disease, he does not have any signs (e.g., ST elevations or Q waves on ECG) or symptoms (e.g., chest pain, diaphoresis, or dyspnea) that suggest myocardial ischemia.

images.title: Acute anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 90/min
– Left axis deviation (R > S in I, S > R in aVF)
– There are both ventricular (green overlay) and supraventricular (purple overlay) extrasystoles.
– ST elevation in all precordial leads (V_1–V_6; example indicated by blue overlay), as well as I, aVL, and -aVR
– Reciprocal ST depression in III (red overlay), and nonsignificantly also in aVF
– Pathological Q waves in V_1–V_4 (yellow overlay)Note that the limb leads of this ECG are arranged differently than usual: in this 'Cabrera' format the limb leads are shown in anatomically contiguous order, as they appear on the Cabrera circle (beginning with aVL and proceeding clockwise). To allow this the format also uses negative aVR (-aVR), which is obtained by simply inverting the polarity of the usual positive aVR. ST elevation in -aVR is therefore equivalent to ST depression in aVR.

answers.explanation_why: Atrial enlargement (e.g., due to fluid overload) is a common contributing factor in the development of postoperative arrhythmias. Moreover, chronic hypertension may lead to left atrial enlargement. However, atrial enlargement leads to supraventricular arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation) rather than ventricular arrhythmias like this patient's PVCs.

images.title: Atrial fibrillation
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25mm/s)- Irregularly irregular rhythm
- Rate ∼ 90/min
- Normal axis
- No discernable P waves
- Coarse fibrillatory waves (f waves) are visible, particularly in II, aVF and V1

images.title: Bigeminy
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Rate: ∼ 70/min
– Rhythm: bigeminy - alternating sinus complexes (examples indicated by green circles) and premature ventricular complexes (PVCs; examples indicated by red lines)
– Axis: normal or slight left axis deviation
– Nonspecific intraventricular conduction delay in the sinus complexes (QRS duration > 0.12 s but no clear right or left bundle branch block morphology)
– The PVCs are unifocal (all PVCs in a given lead look the same, indicating they come from the same focus) and most likely arise in the left ventricle (positive in V1, negative in V5/V6).

question_text: Four days after undergoing a coronary artery bypass graft for coronary artery disease, a 60-year-old man has the onset of abdominal fullness and bloating. Since his surgery, he has not had a bowel movement and is unable to pass flatus. He has no nausea or vomiting. Prior to the operation, the patient had daily bowel movements without abnormalities. He has a history of bipolar disorder and hypertension. His current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, chlorpromazine, amlodipine, and prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows a distended, tympanic abdomen with guarding and rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are hypoactive. Abdominal x-ray shows diffuse distention of the colon loops. A CT scan with contrast confirms the x-ray findings and shows a cecal dilation of 14 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
content_preview: Four days after undergoing a coronary artery bypass graft for coronary artery disease, a 60-year-old man has the onset of abdominal fullness and bloating. Since his surgery, he has not had a bowel movement and is unable to pass flatus. He has no nausea or vomiting. Prior to the operation, the patient had daily bowel movements without abnormalities. He has a history of bipolar disorder and hypertension. His current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, chlorpromazine, amlodipine, and prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows a distended, tympanic abdomen with guarding and rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are hypoactive. Abdominal x-ray shows diffuse distention of the colon loops. A CT scan with contrast confirms the x-ray findings and shows a cecal dilation of 14 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
hint: Abdominal distention and marked dilation of the colon and cecum on imaging indicate acute megacolon. This condition typically occurs as a complication of an interventional procedure and/or a side effect of medications that are known to decrease intestinal motility (e.g., amlodipine, chlorpromazine). The combination of fever, tachycardia, abdominal rebound tenderness, and guarding suggests a case complicated by peritonitis and actual or impending bowel ischemia.
learning_objective: Recognize acute megacolon with complications, and choose the most appropriate surgical intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical decompression for acute megacolon is indicated for patients who do not respond to nonsurgical treatment, and for patients with bowel ischemia, peritonitis, and/or perforation of the colon. Because this patient presents with signs of bowel ischemia and peritonitis, he needs emergency surgical intervention to prevent further complications such as bowel necrosis, sepsis, shock. This patient will require a partial resection of the colon with primary anastomosis of the remaining ends of the colon or a (temporary) colostomy. Cecostomy tube placement would also be an option.

Colonoscopy is an option for decompression of the colon in patients with acute megacolon without concomitant peritonitis. Because this patient presents with signs of peritonitis, he needs a more aggressive approach to prevent bowel necrosis, sepsis, and death.

answers.content: Intravenous fluid therapy and bowel rest only
answers.explanation_why: Although intravenous fluids are indicated in this patient, he is critically ill with signs of peritonitis and actual or impending bowel ischemia. Nonsurgical treatment with bowel rest is not sufficient.

Intravenous neostigmine therapy is an effective pharmacologic treatment for acute megacolon in patients who do not respond to nonpharmacologic treatment after 24–48 hours and/or those with cecal dilation > 12 cm. However, this patient with signs of peritonitis requires a more aggressive approach to prevent bowel necrosis, sepsis, and death.

answers.content: Nasogastric and rectal tube insertion only
answers.explanation_why: A nonsurgical approach to treating acute megacolon involves decompressing the stomach and the colon with nasogastric and rectal tubes, respectively. It is indicated in patients who only have mild symptoms and a cecal dilation < 12 cm. Because this patient has signs of peritonitis and his cecum is 14 cm in diameter, treatment with nasogastric and rectal tube placement alone is insufficient.

question_text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient appears to be in moderate respiratory distress and is cradling his upper left arm in his right arm. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 25/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 108/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows multiple bruises on the left anterior thoracic wall. Jugular venous pulsation is measured at 3 cm above the sternal angle (8 cm H₂O) with the head of the bed elevated at 30 degrees. The trachea is at the midline. On inspiration, his left chest wall moves inwards while his right chest wall is expanding. There is pain to palpation and crepitus over his left anterior ribs. A CT scan confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient appears to be in moderate respiratory distress and is cradling his upper left arm in his right arm. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 25/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 108/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows multiple bruises on the left anterior thoracic wall. Jugular venous pulsation is measured at 3 cm above the sternal angle (8 cm H₂O) with the head of the bed elevated at 30 degrees. The trachea is at the midline. On inspiration, his left chest wall moves inwards while his right chest wall is expanding. There is pain to palpation and crepitus over his left anterior ribs. A CT scan confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: Paradoxical chest movement (inward movement of the chest wall during inspiration) indicates a flail chest, which is a detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to ≥ 3 adjacent rib fractures in ≥ 2 places.
learning_objective: Recognize flail chest, and choose the most appropriate respiratory support.

answers.explanation_why: Needle thoracostomy is performed if the patient has a tension pneumothorax. Although rib fractures can cause a pneumothorax, the absence of tracheal deviation and increased jugular venous pressure makes a tension pneumothorax unlikely.

Rib fractures inhibit deep breathing because of the pain accompanying chest wall expansion. The flail segment further increases the work of breathing and restricts lung volume changes by moving in the direction opposite to thoracic wall movement. The initial management of a flail chest consists of adequate analgesia and supplemental oxygen therapy. Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is indicated if the patient has evidence of respiratory failure. PPV directly assists with alveolar ventilation and gas exchange and may have an internal splinting effect on the flail segment. In patients who are alert and fully oriented, noninvasive PPV may be attempted, but this patient with an altered mental status also requires intubation for airway protection.

If the patient with a flail chest has a concomitant pneumothorax, tube thoracostomy should be performed before initiating PPV to prevent a simple pneumothorax from turning into a life-threatening tension pneumothorax.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

answers.explanation_why: Bedside thoracotomy is indicated as a last resort for cardiac arrest or exsanguinating intrathoracic hemorrhage when all other measures have failed. Although this patient shows respiratory compromise and requires urgent intervention, thoracotomy is not an appropriate treatment for a flail chest.

Pericardiocentesis is indicated for a patient with cardiac tamponade, which can occur following trauma as a result of a hemopericardium. The absence of increased jugular venous pressure makes a cardiac tamponade unlikely.

Surgical fixation may be indicated for patients with flail chest but would not be the first step in treatment of a patient with respiratory distress who does not respond to O_2 supplementation. Indications include gross chest wall deformity and failure to wean the patient off mechanical ventilation, which would be a sign that mechanical ventilation alone does not provide sufficient internal stabilization of the flail segment.

question_text:
Two hours after undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, a 44-year-old man has nausea and pain at the site of surgery. He has vomited twice in the past hour. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include insulin, atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, acetaminophen, and prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. He drinks two to three beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. He is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 130 kg (286 lb); BMI is 42 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Examination shows five laparoscopic incisions with no erythema or discharge. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. There is mild diffuse tenderness to palpation. Bowel sounds are reduced. Laboratory studies show:

Hematocrit
45%

Serum

 Na^+

136 mEq/L

 K^+

3.5 mEq/L

 Cl^-

98 mEq/L

 Urea nitrogen
31 mg/dL

 Glucose
88 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL

Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.28

Pco_2

32 mm Hg

Po_2
54 mm Hg

HCO_3^-
14.4 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acid-base status?
content_preview: Two hours after undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, a 44-year-old man has nausea and pain at the site of surgery. He has vomited twice in the past hour. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include insulin, atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, acetaminophen, and prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. He drinks two to three beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. He is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 130 kg (286 lb); BMI is 42 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Examination shows five laparoscopic incisions with no erythema or discharge. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. There is mild diffuse tenderness to palpation. Bowel sounds are reduced. Laboratory studies show: Hematocrit 45% Serum Na+ 136 mEq/L K+ 3.5 mEq/L Cl- 98 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 31 mg/dL Glucose 88 mg/dL Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.28 Pco2 32 mm Hg Po2 54 mm Hg HCO3- 14.4 mEq/L Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acid-base status?
hint: This patient's arterial blood gas analysis indicates metabolic acidosis (pH < 7.35, bicarbonate < 22) with respiratory compensation (pCO_2  < 35 mm Hg). His high anion gap (136 mEq/l - (98 mEq/L + 14.4 mEq/L) = 23.6 mEq/L) suggests the accumulation of an unmeasured organic anion.
learning_objective: Recognize metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation, and recall the causes of high anion gap acidosis.

answers.explanation_why: This patient underwent Roux-en-Y bypass, which puts him at risk of developing blind loop syndrome. However, blind loop syndrome is a long-term complication of gastric surgery and would not be expected to develop within 2 hours of surgery. Furthermore, it typically does not result in a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Instead, patients may develop non-anion gap metabolic acidosis from chronic diarrhea and subsequent loss of bicarbonate.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) can develop in patients with diabetes mellitus (DM) during times of increased insulin demand (e.g., surgery, infection) and typically leads to high anion gap metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. However, this patient does not have other typical features of DKA, such as hyperglycemia, ketonuria, polyuria, polydipsia, signs of volume depletion, neurological abnormalities, and a fruity breath odor. In addition, DKA is much more common in type 1 DM than in type 2 DM.

Alcohol withdrawal can result in metabolic acidosis with an elevated anion gap in malnourished patients with alcohol use disorder, especially those with a history of binge drinking. During alcohol ingestion, alcoholic carbohydrates are metabolized into energy, inhibiting fatty acid metabolism. However, as a response to alcohol withdrawal, there is a surge in catecholamines and cortisol which augments the metabolism of a fasting state. Consequently, lipolysis and ketone acid production are increased, resulting in metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap (alcoholic ketoacidosis). Although this man's alcohol consumption is borderline high, he does not have any other signs of alcohol withdrawal (e.g., tremors, altered mental state, or hallucinations), nor is he malnourished, making alcohol withdrawal an unlikely etiology of his acid-base disturbance.

Repeated vomiting can result in a significant loss of HCl, NaCl, and KCl, leading to a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis that can be further aggravated by hypovolemia (contraction alkalosis). This patient has metabolic acidosis, which is unlikely to be caused by vomiting.

Dumping syndrome is a complication of gastric surgery, including Roux-en-Y bypass surgery. Symptoms of early dumping syndrome include nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. However, metabolic acidosis is not a typical feature of dumping syndrome. Furthermore, it is unlikely that this patient has developed dumping syndrome only 2 hours after surgery because he is unlikely to have eaten anything yet.

In patients with hypoxia, the lack of oxygen supply to the affected tissue results in anaerobic metabolism and the production of lactic acid, an unmeasured organic anion that lowers the pH. This subsequently causes metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Obese patients who undergo bariatric surgery frequently develop temporary postoperative hypoxemia, as seen in this patient with pO2 of 54 mm Hg. While the pathophysiology behind this is not completely understood, atelectasis-associated ventilation-perfusion mismatch is likely to play a role.

Na^+: sodium
PCO_2: partial pressure of carbon dioxide

question_text: A 25-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department because of an episode of acute psychosis with suicidal ideation. He has no history of serious illness and currently takes no medications. Despite appropriate safety precautions, he manages to leave the examination room unattended. Shortly afterward, he is found lying outside the emergency department. A visitor reports that she saw the patient climbing up the facade of the hospital building. He does not respond to questions but points to his head when asked about pain. His pulse is 131/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 105/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Physical examination shows a 1-cm head laceration and an open fracture of the right tibia. He opens his eyes spontaneously. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Breath sounds are decreased over the right lung field, and the upper right hemithorax is hyperresonant to percussion. There is no jugular venous distension. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department because of an episode of acute psychosis with suicidal ideation. He has no history of serious illness and currently takes no medications. Despite appropriate safety precautions, he manages to leave the examination room unattended. Shortly afterward, he is found lying outside the emergency department. A visitor reports that she saw the patient climbing up the facade of the hospital building. He does not respond to questions but points to his head when asked about pain. His pulse is 131/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 105/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Physical examination shows a 1-cm head laceration and an open fracture of the right tibia. He opens his eyes spontaneously. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Breath sounds are decreased over the right lung field, and the upper right hemithorax is hyperresonant to percussion. There is no jugular venous distension. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Remember the ABCDE approach to trauma management.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for cervical spine protection in a trauma patient, and choose the initial step in airway management.

answers.explanation_why: Needle thoracostomy is indicated for tension pneumothorax causing respiratory compromise. Although this patient likely has pneumothorax (hyperresonance to percussion and decreased breath sounds on examination), he currently does not have signs of severe acute respiratory distress resulting from tension pneumothorax (e.g., jugular venous distention, tracheal deviation, cyanosis). Airway protection should take place before managing a potential tension pneumothorax that is not causing respiratory compromise. Close monitoring for deterioration, for which needle thoracostomy may become necessary, is also indicated.

Endotracheal intubation is indicated for patients with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8 or less because these patients often cannot maintain their airway. This patient has a GCS of 11: He opens his eyes spontaneously (eye opening = 4), obeys commands by localizing pain (motor response = 6), and does not respond verbally to questions (verbal response = 1). Although this patient currently does not need intubation for airway protection, he is still at risk for an injury that further compromises his airway; therefore, part “A” of the ABCDE approach needs to be addressed first.

In patients with blunt trauma to the head and neck, a cervical spine injury should be assumed until proven otherwise. The fact that this patient does not respond verbally to questions despite being conscious raises concern that his airway is compromised. This patient needs a cervical collar to immobilize the cervical spine, ensuring protection of his airway from further damage. This step addresses part “A” (airway assessment and protection) of the ABCDE approach to managing trauma patients.

To diagnose or exclude cervical spine injury, x-ray and CT scan, as well as a physical examination in the form of cervical spine palpation for tenderness, are performed.

answers.content: Place two large bore IV catheters and start two bags of 0.9% saline
answers.explanation_why: This patient will need intravenous fluids to increase his blood pressure of 105/69 mm Hg. Intravenous fluid administration addresses the “C” (circulation and hemorrhage control) of the ABCDE approach to managing trauma patients. Before the administration of fluids, however, this patient needs airway protection; airway (“A”) compromise is more immediately life-threatening than hypotension.

A neurological examination is appropriate once the airway, respiratory (breathing), and circulatory status of this patient have been addressed (parts “A” through “C” of the ABCDE approach to managing trauma patients). The neurological examination is part “D” of the ABCDE approach to neurological disability assessment.

An x-ray in this patient will eventually be necessary to help identify possible rib fractures and pulmonary conditions such as pneumothorax and/or hemothorax. Because this patient likely suffered severe blunt trauma to the head and neck, he may have sustained an airway-compromising injury. Such an injury must be adequately addressed before an x-ray is obtained.

answers.content: Perform open reduction of the tibia fracture
answers.explanation_why: Open reduction of the tibia fracture is not the most appropriate next step in treating this patient who may have an injury that compromises his airway. Before the tibia fracture can be addressed, the ABCDE approach to trauma management needs to be completed in alphabetical order, with an emphasis on “A” or airway management and protection in the patient.

question_text: Two hours following an elective cholecystectomy, a 43-year-old woman has fever and chills. The patient received cephalexin for antibiotic prophylaxis and one unit of packed red blood cells during the procedure. She underwent a hysterectomy 9 years ago for leiomyomata uteri. She has a 5-year history of hypertension treated with lisinopril. Her temperature is 39.5°C (102.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a mildly tender abdominal wound without erythema. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. She had a Foley catheter and peripheral line access placed at the time of the procedure. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Two hours following an elective cholecystectomy, a 43-year-old woman has fever and chills. The patient received cephalexin for antibiotic prophylaxis and one unit of packed red blood cells during the procedure. She underwent a hysterectomy 9 years ago for leiomyomata uteri. She has a 5-year history of hypertension treated with lisinopril. Her temperature is 39.5°C (102.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a mildly tender abdominal wound without erythema. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. She had a Foley catheter and peripheral line access placed at the time of the procedure. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: A Coombs test should be performed next in this patient.
learning_objective: Recognize a febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction.

answers.explanation_why: Medications (e.g., antibiotics) are a common cause of noninfectious postoperative fever. Drug-related fever can cause a broad range of symptoms, from isolated fever to allergic symptoms, such as urticaria, flushing, or pruritus. While this diagnosis cannot be entirely excluded, febrile drug reactions are more common in the subacute phase after surgery (> 1 week postoperatively). Also, the rapid onset of fever in this patient and the circumstances of her surgery suggest an alternative cause.
answers.explanation_but: Drug fever is a diagnosis of exclusion, suggested by the resolution of fever after withdrawal of the offending agent. There is an average of 3–4 days between discontinuation of the drug and resolution of fever.

answers.explanation_why: Malignant hyperthermia is a rare but important cause of perioperative fever that typically causes signs and symptoms within minutes of induction of anesthesia (i.e., intraoperatively), which can include muscle rigidity, hypercarbia, metabolic acidosis, tachycardia, and tachypnea. Fever is usually a late finding in the disease course. Because this patient has isolated postoperative fever, malignant hyperthermia is an unlikely diagnosis.

Surgical site infection is a common cause of postoperative fever that may occur as early as within 24 hours after surgery but usually manifests after 1 week postoperatively. Wound infection would not cause fever within 2 hours of surgery. Additionally, this patient's wound shows no sign of infection, such as erythema, discharge, or severe tenderness.

Although pulmonary embolism can cause postoperative fever, it is also typically associated with some combination of shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, cough, tachycardia, and tachypnea. Pulmonary embolism usually occurs several days to weeks after surgery, not within hours of surgery. In addition, this patient lacks any evidence of deep vein thrombosis (e.g., unilateral leg swelling, redness, tenderness).

Urinary tract infection (UTI) is a common cause of postoperative fever, especially in patients with indwelling urinary catheters and in those who undergo genitourinary procedures. UTI most commonly manifests on postoperative days 2–4 and would not arise within hours of catheter insertion.

Isolated fever within hours of receiving blood products is highly suggestive of febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction. This reaction occurs when preformed recipient antibodies react against remaining donor leukocytes and/or cytokines, which are released after prolonged blood storage. The next best steps are to rule out acute hemolytic transfusion reaction using a direct Coombs test and to administer acetaminophen for symptomatic treatment. Recurrence of nonhemolytic febrile transfusion reactions is rare.
answers.explanation_but: If a patient develops fever during blood transfusion, immediately stop the transfusion!

question_text: A previously healthy 16-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being injured by a dresser falling on him. When the child tried to pull himself up on the dresser, it tipped and fell on his chest and abdomen. He had been awake and agitated at the scene and moved all extremities except for his right arm. On arrival, he is unconscious with rapid, shallow respirations. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 164/min and thready, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 68/35 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bony deformity of the right upper extremity and scattered ecchymoses over the chest and abdomen. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities except for tachycardia. The abdomen is distended with guarding and rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are hypoactive. Attempts to obtain venous access were not successful. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A previously healthy 16-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being injured by a dresser falling on him. When the child tried to pull himself up on the dresser, it tipped and fell on his chest and abdomen. He had been awake and agitated at the scene and moved all extremities except for his right arm. On arrival, he is unconscious with rapid, shallow respirations. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 164/min and thready, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 68/35 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bony deformity of the right upper extremity and scattered ecchymoses over the chest and abdomen. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities except for tachycardia. The abdomen is distended with guarding and rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are hypoactive. Attempts to obtain venous access were not successful. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This pediatric patient who suffered blunt abdominal trauma presents with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and ecchymoses over the chest and abdomen, the combination of which indicates hypovolemic shock as a result of internal hemorrhage. He requires immediate fluid resuscitation.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in the management of a pediatric patient in hypovolemic shock.

answers.content: Central venous line insertion into the right subclavian vein
answers.explanation_why: Central venous lines (CVLs) can be placed for various reasons, including inadequate peripheral venous access, hemodynamic monitoring, and administration of medication. However, this patient presents with signs of severe hypovolemia requiring immediate fluid resuscitation. Subclavian vein cannulation performed during emergencies is accompanied by a variety of complications such as hemothorax or pneumothorax. In addition, CVL insertion requires ultrasound guidance, which would consume valuable time in an emergency such as this. Lastly, since flow rates in CVLs are relatively low given the length of the catheter, a CVL is not the preferred access for emergency fluid resuscitation.

answers.content: Peripherally inserted central catheter insertion into the left basilic vein
answers.explanation_why: Indications for placement of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) include inadequate peripheral venous access, the need for hemodynamic monitoring, and administration of medications such as vasopressors or chemotherapy, which can cause phlebitis when administered through a peripheral IV catheter. Although high-volume fluid therapy can be administered using central catheters, it is not the preferred vascular access for emergencies because central line placement is usually performed under ultrasound guidance and its proper placement is checked by x-ray, which consumes valuable time.

answers.content: Peripheral intravenous line insertion into the left dorsal hand veins
answers.explanation_why: Peripheral IV line insertion is the preferred venous access for fluid resuscitation in trauma patients. However, obtaining peripheral venous access has already been attempted without success and the patient requires immediate fluid resuscitation. Particularly in pediatric trauma patients such as this one, peripheral IV access should be achieved within 60–90 seconds of arrival. If vascular access cannot be obtained in this time, alternative access routes should be considered because another attempt at placing a peripheral IV line would only delay treatment and risk organ damage or even death.

answers.content: Venous cutdown of the great left saphenous vein
answers.explanation_why: Saphenous venous cutdown is a technique used to obtain emergency venous access. However, venous cutdown is time-consuming and has lower placement success rates and higher infectious complication rates compared to other means of vascular access. Although peripheral venous access could not be obtained immediately in this patient, venous cutdown of the great left saphenous vein should only be attempted if other forms of vascular access have also been unsuccessful.

answers.content: Peripheral venous line insertion into the left external jugular vein
answers.explanation_why: Insertion of a peripheral IV line is the preferred venous access for fluid resuscitation in trauma patients. Although insertion into the left external jugular vein can be performed by experienced physicians, it should not be used as a primary site in children with airway compromise or respiratory failure because it requires extension as well as rotation of the neck, thereby putting the patient at unnecessary risk of exacerbating symptoms. Another attempt of placing a peripheral IV line would only delay appropriate treatment and increase the patient's risk of complications (e.g., organ damage), meaning that alternative access routes should be considered.

answers.content: Intraosseous line insertion into the right humerus
answers.explanation_why: Intraosseous (IO) cannulation permits rapid intravascular access for both pediatric and adult patients and is obtained in emergencies because it has a very high success rate. This patient presents with a deformity of the right upper extremity suggestive of a fracture. IO infusion has few absolute contraindications, which include bone fractures, bones previously punctured by IO cannulation, and extremities with vascular interruption because fluids might extravasate into tissue and put the patient at risk for compartment syndrome. In addition, while the humerus is commonly used for IO line insertion in adults, other locations are more frequently used in children.

answers.content: Intraosseous line insertion into the left proximal tibia
answers.explanation_why: Severe hypovolemia in children requires immediate and rapid IV fluid replacement (20 mL/kg) and continuous monitoring until adequate perfusion is reestablished. Since venous access could not be obtained in this patient, an intraosseous (IO) access should be placed. The proximal tibia is the preferred site for IO lines, especially in pediatric patients, as it has the highest success rate.

question_text:
An obese  52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath for the past 8 hours. Two months ago, he noticed a mass on the right side of his neck and was diagnosed with laryngeal cancer. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 27 years. He drinks two pints of rum daily. He appears ill. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Examination shows a 9-cm, tender, firm subglottic mass on the right side of the neck. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. His breathing is labored and he has audible inspiratory stridor but is able to answer questions. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.36

P_CO2
45 mm Hg

P_O2

74 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

25 mEq/L

He has no advanced directive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: An obese 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath for the past 8 hours. Two months ago, he noticed a mass on the right side of his neck and was diagnosed with laryngeal cancer. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 27 years. He drinks two pints of rum daily. He appears ill. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Examination shows a 9-cm, tender, firm subglottic mass on the right side of the neck. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. His breathing is labored and he has audible inspiratory stridor but is able to answer questions. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.36 PCO2 45 mm Hg PO2 74 mm Hg HCO3- 25 mEq/L He has no advanced directive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has untreated laryngeal carcinoma and presents with respiratory distress with stridor and respiratory acidosis.
learning_objective: Recognize laryngeal carcinoma causing respiratory distress, and choose the most appropriate airway management.

answers.explanation_why: A tracheal stent may be used to maintain tracheal patency following surgical resection of this patient's laryngeal cancer. Tracheal stents do not provide a controlled airway and are not used to treat acute respiratory distress.

Tracheostomy is indicated in patients who will require long-term mechanical ventilation and/or in patients with upper airway obstruction causing respiratory distress. This patient will likely need long-term airway management while his laryngeal cancer is managed. Therefore, (percutaneous or open) tracheostomy is the preferred intervention because it will provide an airway that bypasses the tumor and can be used for long-term mechanical ventilation. Although endotracheal intubation would correct this patient's acute respiratory distress, it is not appropriate for long-term airway management (i.e., > 3 weeks), because of the associated risk of complications (e.g., tracheal stenosis, subglottic mass). If this patient were endotracheally intubated, he would eventually need a tracheostomy.

Intramuscular epinephrine is used for acute airway compromise due to anaphylaxis. This patient has not been exposed to a trigger for anaphylaxis (e.g., medication, food allergy, insect bite), however, and he lacks other symptoms of anaphylaxis (e.g., urticaria, itching, angioedema).

Comfort care measures may be appropriate later on in the management of this patient's cancer, if further care is deemed futile or he requests palliative care. However, this patient presents with acute respiratory distress and has no advanced directive, so treatment is indicated.

Cricothyroidotomy is indicated in patients who require emergency temporary airway management and cannot be intubated (e.g., contraindication or failure of endotracheal intubation). While this patient requires urgent airway management, he is conscious, responsive, and hemodynamically stable. Furthermore, he will likely need long-term (> 3 weeks) mechanical ventilation given the chronic nature of his airway obstruction and cricothyroidotomy is not indicated for long-term mechanical ventilation. Finally, because this patient's laryngeal mass is in the subglottic region (i.e., the area where an endotracheal tube would be inserted in a cricothyroidotomy), a cricothyroidotomy is contraindicated.

question_text: A 28-year-old man is scheduled for skin grafting of the right leg. Four weeks earlier, he underwent open reduction and internal fixation of an open right tibial fracture. The postoperative period at that time was complicated by necrosis of the overlying skin. In the operating room, he is placed on continuous hemodynamic monitoring and anesthetized with intrathecal bupivacaine injected into the L3–L4 spinal interspace. Thirty minutes later, he has severe shortness of breath and lightheadedness and loses consciousness. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 38/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 82/50 mm Hg. Examination shows flushed skin. He withdraws the upper extremities to painful stimuli above the navel. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man is scheduled for skin grafting of the right leg. Four weeks earlier, he underwent open reduction and internal fixation of an open right tibial fracture. The postoperative period at that time was complicated by necrosis of the overlying skin. In the operating room, he is placed on continuous hemodynamic monitoring and anesthetized with intrathecal bupivacaine injected into the L3–L4 spinal interspace. Thirty minutes later, he has severe shortness of breath and lightheadedness and loses consciousness. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 38/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 82/50 mm Hg. Examination shows flushed skin. He withdraws the upper extremities to painful stimuli above the navel. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Hypotension and bradycardia following spinal anesthesia suggest neurogenic shock.
learning_objective: Recognize neurogenic shock, and recall its association with spinal anesthesia.

answers.explanation_why:
Local spinal anesthetics can interrupt the transmission of nerve impulses in spinal sympathetic pathways, causing a loss of sympathetic vascular tone that ultimately results in neurogenic shock. Neurogenic shock is a type of distributive shock characterized by generalized vasodilation (causing flushed skin). This vasodilation leads to decreased preload and subsequently reduced cardiac output, which results in severe hypotension. Bradycardia results from lack of beta-adrenergic activity and is exacerbated by unopposed parasympathetic tone (vagal tone). Consequently, cerebral perfusion is impaired, leading to loss of consciousness as seen in this patient. Treatment for neurogenic shock secondary to spinal anesthesia usually involves IV fluids and pressor therapy until the concentration of anesthetic agent has decreased adequately.

See “Overview of the types of shock” table.

Bacterial toxin-induced vasodilation is the mechanism underlying septic shock. Although septic shock also causes warm, flushed skin secondary to vasodilation during the early, hyperdynamic phase, it is also characterized by increased cardiac output and tachycardia, which are absent in this patient. Also, he does not show signs of active infection such as fever or hypothermia, making septic shock unlikely. In addition, septic shock generally does not develop hyperacutely over the course of minutes as seen here.

answers.content: Obstructive thrombus in the pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: An obstructive thrombus in the pulmonary artery results in pulmonary embolism (PE). This patient is at risk of developing thromboembolism given his history of trauma and immobilization of the lower extremity. Although he also has shortness of breath, tachypnea, and hypotension (which may indicate a severe PE), pulmonary embolism generally leads to tachycardia instead of bradycardia. Also, PE would not explain the flushed, diaphoretic skin, which is a sign of venous vasodilation.

Intravascular volume depletion is the mechanism underlying hemorrhagic (hypovolemic) shock. Patients with hemorrhagic shock usually have a history of severe volume depletion or fluid shift (recent trauma, burns, vomiting/diarrhea), which is not the case in this patient. Although hemorrhagic shock can also cause bradycardia and hypotension, reflex tachycardia is usually present as well. Because this patient is bradycardic, hypovolemic shock is unlikely.

answers.content: Bone marrow embolism to the lungs
answers.explanation_why: Bone marrow embolism to the lungs is the underlying pathophysiology of fat embolism. Although this patient's recent open tibial fracture puts him at risk for developing fat embolism, the symptoms of this condition usually develop 12–72 hours after orthopedic trauma/surgery; this patient's surgery was 4 weeks ago. Patients with fat embolism often present with a petechial rash over the head, neck, or thorax, and tachycardia, not bradycardia.

Type I hypersensitivity reaction is the pathomechanism of anaphylactic shock. Although patients with anaphylactic shock also present with shortness of breath and hypotension, they typically have tachycardia, not bradycardia. Other signs of type I hypersensitivity reaction such as urticaria, angioedema, or abnormal lung sounds such as wheezing or stridor are also absent in this patient.
