question_text: Three days after being admitted to the hospital because of a fall from the roof of a two-story building, a 27-year-old man is being monitored in the intensive care unit. On arrival, the patient was somnolent and not oriented to person, place, or time. A CT scan of the head showed an epidural hemorrhage that was 45 mL in size and a midline shift of 7 mm; no skull fracture was shown. Emergency surgery was performed with craniotomy and hematoma evacuation on the day of admission. Perioperatively, a bleeding vessel was identified and ligated. Postoperatively, the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit and placed on a ventilator. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 117/78 mm Hg. The ventilator is set at a FiO_2 of 55%, tidal volume of 520 mL, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 5.0 cm H_2O. In addition to intravenous administration of fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's nutrition?
content_preview: Three days after being admitted to the hospital because of a fall from the roof of a two-story building, a 27-year-old man is being monitored in the intensive care unit. On arrival, the patient was somnolent and not oriented to person, place, or time. A CT scan of the head showed an epidural hemorrhage that was 45 mL in size and a midline shift of 7 mm; no skull fracture was shown. Emergency surgery was performed with craniotomy and hematoma evacuation on the day of admission. Perioperatively, a bleeding vessel was identified and ligated. Postoperatively, the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit and placed on a ventilator. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 117/78 mm Hg. The ventilator is set at a FiO2 of 55%, tidal volume of 520 mL, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 5.0 cm H2O. In addition to intravenous administration of fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's nutrition?
hint: Nutritional support primarily depends on whether a patient is on ventilation (and, if so, for how long) and whether intestinal decompression is required.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in managing nutrition for a ventilated patient postoperatively.

answers.explanation_why: Critically ill patients with an intact gastrointestinal tract can receive short-term enteral feeding via nasogastric tube (< 2–3 weeks) if there are no contraindications (e.g., bowel obstruction, intractable vomiting, hemodynamic instability). Enteral feeding is preferred over parenteral nutrition because it stimulates intestinal motility and prevents mucosal atrophy. As long as there is no facial trauma or basilar skull fractures, a nasogastric tube can be used for enteral feeding. When feeding, patients should have their backrest elevated to prevent aspiration and reduce the incidence of nosocomial pneumonia.

Nutritional support is indicated in critically ill patients with a low Glasgow coma scale who cannot be fed. Keeping the patient nil per os would only be indicated for the first 48 hours following surgery in case repeat surgery is necessary.

answers.content: Enteral feeding using a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube
answers.explanation_why: A percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube would only be considered for long-term enteral feeding, as temporary routes such as nasogastric or nasoenteric tubes often fail with long-term use because of clogging and inadvertent dislodgement. However, for the short term, a PEG tube would be too invasive in a patient with a potentially reversible condition.

Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) via an intravenous line bypasses the gastrointestinal tract. The lack of intestinal stimulation increases the risk of intestinal atrophy, increases bowel wall permeability, and alters the gut flora, making TPN inferior to other feeding methods. TPN is only indicated in patients without a functioning gastrointestinal tract (e.g., short bowel syndrome, severe malabsorption) or when complete bowel rest is indicated (e.g., bowel obstruction).
Oral feeding would be inappropriate because the patient is on mechanical ventilation with an endotracheal tube. He cannot ingest food by mouth.

question_text: A 68-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit after open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. The patient has received 4 units of packed red blood cells during the surgery. During the first 24 hours following the procedure, he has only passed 200 mL of urine. He has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Current medications include atenolol, enalapril, and spironolactone. He appears ill. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and flat neck veins. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 48 mg/dL. His serum creatinine and BUN on admission were 1.2 mg/dL and 18 mg/dL, respectively. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit after open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. The patient has received 4 units of packed red blood cells during the surgery. During the first 24 hours following the procedure, he has only passed 200 mL of urine. He has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Current medications include atenolol, enalapril, and spironolactone. He appears ill. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and flat neck veins. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 48 mg/dL. His serum creatinine and BUN on admission were 1.2 mg/dL and 18 mg/dL, respectively. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient's oliguria in combination with increased BUN and creatinine levels suggests acute kidney injury (AKI). The onset of AKI one day after surgery in a patient with signs of hypovolemia (e.g., tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, flat neck veins) and a BUN:creatinine ratio > 20:1 is consistent with prerenal AKI.
learning_objective: Recognize prerenal acute kidney injury, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: Intrinsic causes of AKI typically manifest with a decreased urine osmolality (< 350 mOsmol/kg H_2O), as the kidney loses the ability to concentrate the urine. Acute tubular necrosis (e.g., due to hypoxia) is the most common cause of AKI in the postoperative period. However, the BUN:creatinine ratio is decreased (≤ 15:1) in patients with intrinsic AKI because the renal damage causes decreased urea reabsorption. This patient's increased BUN:creatinine ratio (> 20:1) is more consistent with prerenal AKI, in which urea reabsorption is increased.
answers.explanation_but: This patient, who underwent major surgery with loss of large amounts of blood, is at risk for hypoxic damage to the kidney. Prerenal AKI can lead to intrinsic AKI if causes of renal hypoxia (e.g., hypovolemia and/or hypotension) are not treated.

answers.explanation_why: WBC casts are a typical finding in patients with pyelonephritis and tubulointerstitial diseases, such as acute interstitial nephritis and renal papillary necrosis. Pyelonephritis most commonly manifests with high fevers, chills, flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, and symptoms of cystitis (e.g., dysuria, frequency, or urgency), which are absent in this patient. Although tubulointerstitial diseases commonly manifest with elevated levels of BUN and creatinine and may result in acute kidney injury, additional symptoms (e.g., flank pain) are usually present. Also, the BUN:creatinine ratio would not be increased.

Damage to any part of the urinary tract may result in hematuria. Hematuria in combination with oliguria and azotemia is a typical finding in nephritic syndrome. However, patients with nephritic syndrome usually have features of hypervolemia (e.g., mild to moderate edema, hypertension) rather than hypovolemia.

Patients with prerenal AKI typically present with a decreased urine sodium concentration (< 20 mmol/L). Prerenal AKI due to hypovolemia causes renal hypoperfusion rather than direct damage to the nephrons. The kidneys physiologically respond to hypoperfusion by reabsorbing large amounts of sodium, which is then followed by water. As a result, the excreted urine contains low amounts of sodium and is concentrated.

In intrinsic AKI (caused by direct kidney damage), the function of the tubular system is impaired, leading to reduced reabsorption of sodium and a urine sodium concentration > 40 mmol/L.

Proteinuria results from direct kidney injury secondary to damage to the glomeruli (e.g., glomerulonephritis, diabetic nephropathy), damage to the tubules (e.g., Fanconi syndrome), or overproduction of low molecular weight proteins (e.g., multiple myeloma). Patients with intrinsic AKI may also present with oliguria and azotemia, as seen here. However, signs of hypervolemia (e.g., edema), rather than hypovolemia (dry mucous membranes and flat neck veins in this patient), would be expected in intrinsic AKI, as the kidneys are unable to effectively remove excess fluid from the body.

question_text: A 22-year-old man develops agitation and restlessness one hour after undergoing an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy. He also has tremors, diffuse sweating, headache, and nausea with dry heaves. Intraoperatively, there was approximately 100 mL of blood loss, his urine output was 100 mL, and 1 L of lactated Ringer solution was administered. His pain has been controlled with intravenous morphine. He was admitted to the hospital 3 days ago and has not eaten in 18 hours. He has no history of serious illness. He has experimented with intravenous illicit drugs. He drinks 3 beers and 2 glasses of whiskey daily during the week and more on the weekends with his college fraternity. He appears anxious. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, but not to time or place, and keeps asking if his father, who is not present, can leave the room. Mucous membranes are moist and the skin is warm. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia and regular rhythm. The lungs are clear to auscultation. His abdomen has three port sites with clean and dry bandages. His hands tremble when his arms are extended with fingers spread apart. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man develops agitation and restlessness one hour after undergoing an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy. He also has tremors, diffuse sweating, headache, and nausea with dry heaves. Intraoperatively, there was approximately 100 mL of blood loss, his urine output was 100 mL, and 1 L of lactated Ringer solution was administered. His pain has been controlled with intravenous morphine. He was admitted to the hospital 3 days ago and has not eaten in 18 hours. He has no history of serious illness. He has experimented with intravenous illicit drugs. He drinks 3 beers and 2 glasses of whiskey daily during the week and more on the weekends with his college fraternity. He appears anxious. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, but not to time or place, and keeps asking if his father, who is not present, can leave the room. Mucous membranes are moist and the skin is warm. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia and regular rhythm. The lungs are clear to auscultation. His abdomen has three port sites with clean and dry bandages. His hands tremble when his arms are extended with fingers spread apart. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: This patient has an excessive drinking pattern that was disrupted for the past 3 days because of admission to the hospital. He now has sympathetic overstimulation (anxiety, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, and tremors), altered mental status, and visual hallucinations that are characteristic of alcohol withdrawal delirium, which typically occurs 72–96 hours after abrupt cessation of alcohol.
learning_objective: Recognize alcohol withdrawal syndrome, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous propranolol is used in combination with antithyroid drugs to treat thyroid storm, which can occur after a stressful event (e.g., infection, surgery) in patients with hyperthyroidism and manifest with altered mental status and signs of sympathetic overstimulation. However, the severity of tachycardia is far greater in thyroid storm (heart rate usually exceeds 140/minute) and severe hyperpyrexia (> 104°F) is also typically present. The lack of a history of hyperthyroidism also makes a thyroid storm unlikely.

Alcohol activates GABA (inhibitory) receptors and chronic alcohol use downregulates GABA receptors. The abrupt cessation of a GABAergic agent (e.g., alcohol) in a patient with downregulated GABA receptors causes neuronal hyperexcitability, which is responsible for the manifestations of alcohol withdrawal, including alcohol withdrawal delirium. This condition may be lethal and must be treated urgently. The first-line therapy for alcohol withdrawal delirium is an intravenous benzodiazepine (e.g., lorazepam). Benzodiazepines are GABAergic agents and counteract neuronal hyperexcitability.

Intravenous naloxone is the first-line treatment for opioid overdose. This patient has received intravenous morphine, an opiate analgesic, for pain control. However, morphine results in decreased responsiveness, respiratory depression, and miosis. This patient has a normal respiratory rate, is alert and oriented, and does not have any pupillary abnormalities, making an opioid overdose unlikely.

Intravenous dexamethasone may be used to treat an adrenal crisis, which can occur following periods of acute stress (e.g., surgery) in patients with adrenal insufficiency and manifest with nausea and an altered mental status. However, patients with an adrenal crisis would have hypotension. The lack of a history of adrenal insufficiency also makes an adrenal crisis unlikely.

5% dextrose in half normal saline can be administered to treat severe hypernatremia, which can occur in the postoperative period as a result of dehydration and cause delirium. This patient, however, has no features suggestive of dehydration (e.g., dry mucous membranes, hypotension).

Dantrolene is used as first-line therapy for malignant hyperthermia, which occurs in the immediate postoperative period (as a result of the administration of medications for general anesthesia) and can manifest with diaphoresis and tachycardia. However, it usually also manifests with severe hyperthermia and muscle rigidity, neither of which are seen in this patient.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. The patient reports severe pelvic pain. Pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Current medications include insulin, folic acid, and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The cervix is 100% effaced and 10 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is reactive with no decelerations. Epidural anesthesia is performed and the patient's symptoms improve. Ten minutes later, the patient has dizziness. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's hypotension?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. The patient reports severe pelvic pain. Pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Current medications include insulin, folic acid, and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The cervix is 100% effaced and 10 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is reactive with no decelerations. Epidural anesthesia is performed and the patient's symptoms improve. Ten minutes later, the patient has dizziness. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's hypotension?
learning_objective: Recognize sympathetic block as a cause of hypotension post-epidural anesthesia.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased cardiac contractility resulting in reduced cardiac output and subsequent hypotension is commonly caused by myocardial ischemia, heart failure, and cardiac arrhythmias. While some conditions that reduce cardiac contractility are associated specifically with pregnancy (e.g., peripartum cardiomyopathy), heart disease is unlikely in a patient with no history of or current cardiac symptoms.

This patient's onset of hypotension shortly after receiving epidural anesthesia indicates a sympathetic blockade. The anesthetic blocks sympathetic nerve conduction, causing peripheral vasodilation and decreased venous return to the heart. The subsequent decrease in cardiac output, in combination with the reduced total peripheral resistance, leads to the development of hypotension shortly after performing epidural anesthesia. Treatment consists of IV fluid resuscitation and small doses of epinephrine.

images.title: Epidural anesthesia (2/2): procedure
images.description:
The injection site may be at any vertebral level (cervical, thoracic, and lumbar). This illustration shows a midline approach, but a paramedian approach is also possible.(1) Local anesthetic is infiltrated into the subcutaneous tissue (1a) and interspinous ligament (1b).
(2) The epidural needle is inserted, angled slightly cephalad with the bevel orientated cephalad. Once the needle has been advanced by about 2–3 cm into the interspinous ligament, the stylet is removed and a loss-of-resistance syringe filled with saline is attached.
(3) The needle is advanced while applying constant, gentle pressure on the syringe plunger. After passing through the ligamentum flavum and entering the epidural space, a sudden loss of resistance is felt and the saline is more easily injected (3a); at this point, advancement is stopped.
(4) The syringe is removed and the epidural catheter is inserted through the needle to its correct depth (puncture depth + 4–6 cm). The tip of the catheter must always be advanced cephalad (4a); therefore, the bevel of the needle must remain facing cephalad.
(5) The epidural needle is removed, taking care to maintain the epidural catheter at the correct depth. At this time, aspiration is attempted from the catheter (5a: this should return neither blood nor CSF), and an epidural filter is attached (5b).
(6) The puncture site is covered with a transparent dressing and the catheter is secured to the patient's back with adherent dressings. A test dose is then administered.

answers.explanation_why: The most common cause of sudden hypotension in pregnant women is hypovolemia secondary to hemorrhage. Although vaginal bleeding as an indicator of hemorrhage may not always be present (e.g., concealed placental abruption), this patient's history suggests another diagnosis.

Obstruction of the pulmonary artery (pulmonary embolism) can lead to increased pressure in the right ventricle with subsequent pressure overload and enlargement. The resulting reduced left ventricular preload decreases cardiac output, leading to hypotension and tachycardia. Although the sudden onset of hypotension in a pregnant woman should raise suspicion of pulmonary embolism or even amniotic fluid embolism, this diagnosis is unlikely in the absence of further characteristic findings (e.g., dyspnea, tachypnea, cyanosis, disseminated intravascular coagulation).

Aortocaval compression can cause supine hypotensive syndrome, a condition in which maternal vessels are compressed by the uterus when the mother is lying in a supine position. The resulting impaired blood supply can lead to maternal hypotension and fetal hypoxemia with bradycardia. While supine hypotensive syndrome should always be considered in hypotensive pregnant women, the normal fetal heart rate makes this diagnosis unlikely.

question_text: Two days after spontaneous vaginal delivery, a 23-year-old woman is evaluated for persistent, throbbing pain at the back of her head. The pain began yesterday and radiates to the neck and shoulder area. She also has nausea and has had one episode of clear vomitus. The symptoms are exacerbated when she gets up from bed, and they have not improved despite starting acetaminophen and bed rest one day prior. Her pregnancy was uncomplicated and the patient attended all prenatal health visits. She underwent epidural analgesia for delivery. Her postpartum course was free of obstetric complications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. She is alert and oriented. On examination, neck stiffness is present. Neurologic examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Two days after spontaneous vaginal delivery, a 23-year-old woman is evaluated for persistent, throbbing pain at the back of her head. The pain began yesterday and radiates to the neck and shoulder area. She also has nausea and has had one episode of clear vomitus. The symptoms are exacerbated when she gets up from bed, and they have not improved despite starting acetaminophen and bed rest one day prior. Her pregnancy was uncomplicated and the patient attended all prenatal health visits. She underwent epidural analgesia for delivery. Her postpartum course was free of obstetric complications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. She is alert and oriented. On examination, neck stiffness is present. Neurologic examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's positional headache (worse when upright), nausea, and neck stiffness raise suspicion for post-lumbar puncture headache caused by accidental dural puncture during epidural placement.
learning_objective: Recognize post-lumbar puncture headache, and choose the most appropriate management for severe or refractory symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: Magnesium sulfate can be used as prophylaxis for eclampsia in patients with preeclampsia. Headache is a feature of preeclampsia (both with and without severe features), which occurs rarely after delivery. However, a diagnosis of preeclampsia requires hypertension; this patient has normal blood pressure.

CT angiography of the head can help identify the source of an intracranial hemorrhage or cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT), for which pregnancy is a risk factor. Intracranial hemorrhage and CVT can manifest with headache, nausea, and vomiting. However, this patient does not have other typical findings, such as papilledema and focal neurologic deficits. Furthermore, a noncontrast CT scan rather than CT angiography would be the initial test of choice.

answers.content: Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis
answers.explanation_why: Cerebrospinal fluid analysis is used to diagnose central nervous system infection (e.g., meningitis), autoimmune syndromes (e.g., multiple sclerosis), and malignancy. Neck stiffness, nausea, and vomiting can be seen in patients with meningitis caused by a septic epidural placement, but this complication is very rare and the absence of fever makes the diagnosis less likely. Performing another puncture for CSF fluid analysis would most likely worsen this patient's symptoms.

answers.content: Continued bed rest and analgesic therapy
answers.explanation_why: Continued bed rest and analgesic therapy alone are not sufficient for this patient, who has not improved with these conservative measures. Moreover, this patient has features of severe headache (throbbing headache with vomiting and neck stiffness), which, in combination with unsuccessful conservative management, requires further treatment.

An epidural blood patch is indicated for severe or refractory post-lumbar puncture headaches resulting from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak syndrome. Autologous blood injected at the site of the lumbar puncture seals the hole in the dura and resolves the CSF leak that is causing the postural headache. Initial management (oral analgesics and bed rest) has not improved this patient's symptoms, making an epidural blood patch the most appropriate next step in management. Additional management includes sufficient fluid intake.

Sumatriptan is used as an abortive medication for migraine headaches. Although this patient presents with neck stiffness, nausea, and vomiting, the worsening postural headache that developed after epidural anesthesia indicates a post-lumbar puncture headache rather than a migraine.

question_text: Thirty minutes after surgical nasal polyp removal for refractory rhinitis, a 40-year-old man has retrosternal chest tightness and shortness of breath in the post-anesthesia care unit. The surgical course was uncomplicated, and the patient was successfully extubated before arrival to the unit. He received 0.5 L of lactated Ringer solution intraoperatively. The patient was given morphine and ketorolac for postoperative pain. A similar episode happened 6 months ago when the patient took aspirin for a headache; symptoms resolved spontaneously within 3 hours. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea, asthma, and hypertension. His daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen by face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Wheezing is heard in both lungs. Breath sounds are decreased. The patient's face appears flushed. Watery nasal secretions and conjunctival injection are present. ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Thirty minutes after surgical nasal polyp removal for refractory rhinitis, a 40-year-old man has retrosternal chest tightness and shortness of breath in the post-anesthesia care unit. The surgical course was uncomplicated, and the patient was successfully extubated before arrival to the unit. He received 0.5 L of lactated Ringer solution intraoperatively. The patient was given morphine and ketorolac for postoperative pain. A similar episode happened 6 months ago when the patient took aspirin for a headache; symptoms resolved spontaneously within 3 hours. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea, asthma, and hypertension. His daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen by face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Wheezing is heard in both lungs. Breath sounds are decreased. The patient's face appears flushed. Watery nasal secretions and conjunctival injection are present. ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma together constitute Samter triad.
learning_objective: Recognize a pseudoallergic reaction.

answers.explanation_why:
The use of non-selective beta-blockers can result in bronchospasm due to the inhibition of β_2 receptors on the bronchial wall. However, metoprolol is a beta-blocker that selectively inhibits β_1 receptors. It is therefore not the most likely cause of bronchospasm in this patient.

All beta-blockers can trigger bronchospasms in patients with asthma and β1-receptor selectivity is diminished in higher doses. Therefore, beta-blockers should be avoided in patients with severe or decompensated asthma. However, therapeutic doses of cardioselective beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are generally well tolerated in patients with mild to moderate asthma.

Hyperinflation of the lungs in a patient with emphysema can result in iatrogenic alveolar rupture; a 20-pack-year smoking history and the recent mechanical ventilation (intubated patient!) are therefore risk factors for alveolar rupture. Alveolar rupture would result in a pneumothorax, which presents with dyspnea and decreased breath sounds on the side of the pneumothorax. This patient developed wheezing and decreased breath sounds bilaterally after an infusion of ketorolac, making alveolar rupture unlikely.

Samter triad is a feature of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Patients with AERD develop symptoms resembling those of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction (e.g., wheezing, decreased breath sounds, facial flushing) following the administration of aspirin or NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac). Watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are also commonly seen in AERD. Unlike a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, which is an IgE-mediated process, AERD is a pseudoallergic reaction caused by the inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX). Inhibition of the COX pathway increases the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes via the lipoxygenases pathway. Leukotrienes cause flushing and bronchial inflammation.

A type 1 hypersensitivity reaction causes bronchospasm and facial flushing. However, watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are not expected. These features combined with chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma make another cause more likely.

ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril can cause accumulation of bradykinin by inhibiting the enzyme bradykinin dehydrogenase. Increased levels of bradykinin typically result in a dry cough or angioedema, neither of which is seen in this patient. Bradykinin does have some bronchoconstrictor effect, especially if the patient has an underlying airway hyperreactivity (bronchial asthma). However, Samter triad and the onset of symptoms following the administration of ketorolac indicate a different mechanism for bronchospasm.

question_text: A 46-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a bicycle accident during which she fell on her head and right shoulder. On arrival, she is awake and alert. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and panic attacks. She has a history of alcohol use disorder but says that she has not had an alcoholic drink for 1 month. On examination, there is a hematoma on her left temple and her right shoulder joint appears dislocated. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. X-ray of the right shoulder confirms uncomplicated dislocation. The patient receives intravenous midazolam and fentanyl as procedural sedation for closed shoulder reduction. Following the procedure, the patient remains sedated for a prolonged time and the physician decides to reverse sedation pharmacologically. After administration of naloxone and flumazenil, the patient develops a tonic-clonic seizure lasting for one minute. Her pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient appears drowsy and diaphoretic. Examination shows a tremor in both hands. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's seizure?
content_preview: A 46-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a bicycle accident during which she fell on her head and right shoulder. On arrival, she is awake and alert. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and panic attacks. She has a history of alcohol use disorder but says that she has not had an alcoholic drink for 1 month. On examination, there is a hematoma on her left temple and her right shoulder joint appears dislocated. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. X-ray of the right shoulder confirms uncomplicated dislocation. The patient receives intravenous midazolam and fentanyl as procedural sedation for closed shoulder reduction. Following the procedure, the patient remains sedated for a prolonged time and the physician decides to reverse sedation pharmacologically. After administration of naloxone and flumazenil, the patient develops a tonic-clonic seizure lasting for one minute. Her pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient appears drowsy and diaphoretic. Examination shows a tremor in both hands. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's seizure?
hint: This patient has features of dysautonomia and neurological symptoms (e.g., seizure, tremor) shortly after administration of antagonizing agents.
learning_objective: Recognize benzodiazepine withdrawal as a cause of seizure following flumazenil administration.

answers.explanation_why: Severe hypoglycemia (blood glucose < 40 mg/dL) can precipitate seizures and manifest with tremors, tachycardia, sweating, and altered mental status. This patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for which she may be taking insulin or noninsulin antidiabetic drugs (e.g., sulfonylureas, meglitinides) that increase her risk of hypoglycemia. However, the seizure followed the administration of an antagonizing agent, which makes another cause more likely.

Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist that can cause acute benzodiazepine withdrawal and may precipitate seizures in patients with high tolerance from chronic use. Therefore, indications for flumazenil are narrow, such as the treatment of oversedation and/or overdose in benzodiazepine-naive patients. This patient has a history of panic attacks, for which she is likely taking benzodiazepines. Her seizure following flumazenil administration was likely caused by withdrawal.

Severe respiratory depression from isolated benzodiazepine poisoning is very rare and usually only occurs with coingestion of alcohol, opioids, barbiturates, first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine), and other respiratory or CNS depressants. Expectant management and supportive care are sufficient for most patients with isolated benzodiazepine overdose. Patients undergoing flumazenil therapy require careful monitoring by a specialist.

Alcohol withdrawal is a common cause of seizures in adults and typically occurs 8–48 hours after decreasing or stopping alcohol consumption. Although this patient has a history of alcohol use disorder, her last alcoholic drink was 1 month ago, and her seizure occurred shortly after the administration of an antagonizing agent, which makes another cause more likely.

Opiate (e.g., fentanyl) overdose can cause severe respiratory depression, especially when opiates are combined with benzodiazepines (e.g., in procedural sedation). Prolonged respiratory depression can lead to anoxic brain injury manifesting with seizures. However, anoxic or hypoxic brain injury from prolonged respiratory depression is typically delayed (∼24 hours) rather than immediate. Finally, if fentanyl overdose had been the cause of this patient's seizure, naloxone administration would have prevented it.

A subdural hematoma can manifest with seizures and should be considered in patients following head trauma. Patients can have a lucid interval between injury and the onset of neurological symptoms. Unlike this patient, individuals with subdural hematoma usually deteriorate rapidly and commonly have focal neurological deficits, pupillary abnormalities, and signs of increased intracranial pressure or herniation. Furthermore, this patient's seizure occurred shortly after the administration of an antagonizing agent, which makes another cause more likely.

question_text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency room for worsening leg pain and a rash consistent with wet gangrene. He has no history of skin infections but has type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Three days after admission, he becomes increasingly hypoxic and tachypneic. He is emergently intubated and ventilatory support is initiated. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. His pulse is 112/min and blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg. The ventilator is set at a tidal volume of 540 mL, respiratory rate of 20/min, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cm H_2O. On pulmonary examination, there are diffuse crackles. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Hemoglobin concentration is 11.5 g/dL, serum lactate is 4.0 mmol/L, and serum creatinine is 2.5 mg/dL. An arterial blood gas checked 30 minutes after intubation shows a PCO_2 of 50 mm Hg and a PO_2 of 55 mm Hg on an F_IO_2 of 1.0. An x-ray of the chest shows new bilateral infiltrates. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to improve tissue oxygen delivery in this patient?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency room for worsening leg pain and a rash consistent with wet gangrene. He has no history of skin infections but has type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Three days after admission, he becomes increasingly hypoxic and tachypneic. He is emergently intubated and ventilatory support is initiated. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. His pulse is 112/min and blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg. The ventilator is set at a tidal volume of 540 mL, respiratory rate of 20/min, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cm H2O. On pulmonary examination, there are diffuse crackles. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Hemoglobin concentration is 11.5 g/dL, serum lactate is 4.0 mmol/L, and serum creatinine is 2.5 mg/dL. An arterial blood gas checked 30 minutes after intubation shows a PCO2 of 50 mm Hg and a PO2 of 55 mm Hg on an FIO2 of 1.0. An x-ray of the chest shows new bilateral infiltrates. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to improve tissue oxygen delivery in this patient?
hint: This patient has an acute onset of hypoxemia with bilateral infiltrates on imaging. This presentation is concerning for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), especially in the setting of his ongoing infection (wet gangrene). His P_aO_2/F_iO_2 ratio is less than 100, which categorizes his ARDS as severe and carries a high mortality risk.
learning_objective: Recognize acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and choose the most appropriate ventilator management.

answers.explanation_why: Inhaled nitric oxide is used in the treatment of certain patients with severe pulmonary hypertension by improving pulmonary vasodilation. This patient does not have any history to suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension (e.g., signs of right heart failure like edema) and it is not an effective treatment for ARDS.

Early prone positioning can improve oxygenation and has been shown to decrease the length of hospitalization and increase survival in patients with ARDS. Prone positioning, however, is technically difficult and is usually only pursued after alternative interventions to stabilize the patient's oxygenation have been attempted.

Generally, increasing the tidal volume will increase the volume of oxygen delivered to alveoli and can often improve oxygenation in most cases. However, the high peak pressures and lung distention associated with high tidal volumes in patients with ARDS increase the risk of barotrauma and worsening respiratory distress. Using lower tidal volumes (lung protective ventilation of ∼ 6 mL/kg) improves mortality risk in patients with ARDS, and mild hypercapnia is tolerated in this regard (permissive hypercapnia).

ARDS is a syndrome with complex pathophysiology characterized by diffuse alveolar damage, leading to pulmonary edema, alveolar collapse, and impairment in gas exchange. Increasing the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) will help distend the alveoli (thereby increasing alveolar ventilation as well as decreasing the work of breathing) and increase oxygen diffusion into the pulmonary capillaries. Patients with severe ARDS often require higher levels of PEEP to help recruit alveoli and improve gas exchange. Since this patient is already at maximum F_iO_2 and is on appropriate lung-protective ventilation settings (tidal volume of 6 mL/kg), increasing PEEP would be the most appropriate next step in management.

Transfusion of RBCs can increase the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, although this effect is minimal. Hypoxia in acute respiratory distress syndrome is a result of impaired gas exchange at the capillary-alveolar interface, so a blood transfusion will not improve his oxygenation.

question_text: Three hours after undergoing open proctocolectomy for ulcerative colitis, a 42-year-old man complains of abdominal pain. The pain is localized to the periumbilical and hypogastric regions. A total of 20 mL of urine has drained from his urinary catheter since the end of the procedure. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Physical examination shows a 20-cm vertical midline incision and an ileostomy in the right lower quadrant. There is no fluid drainage from the surgical wounds. The urinary catheter flushes easily and is without obstruction. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a blood urea nitrogen of 30 mg/dL and a creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Three hours after undergoing open proctocolectomy for ulcerative colitis, a 42-year-old man complains of abdominal pain. The pain is localized to the periumbilical and hypogastric regions. A total of 20 mL of urine has drained from his urinary catheter since the end of the procedure. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Physical examination shows a 20-cm vertical midline incision and an ileostomy in the right lower quadrant. There is no fluid drainage from the surgical wounds. The urinary catheter flushes easily and is without obstruction. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a blood urea nitrogen of 30 mg/dL and a creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A urine output of < 0.5 mL/kg/hr for > 2 hours in a patient who has recently undergone surgery is consistent with postoperative oliguria. A BUN:creatinine ratio > 20:1 suggests a prerenal cause for the low urine output. This patient's abdominal pain is most likely due to surgery, and his vital signs are reassuring.
learning_objective: Recognize postoperative oliguria, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Furosemide can be used in patients with acute kidney injury with signs of volume overload. This patient, however, does not have peripheral edema or evidence of pulmonary edema to suggest fluid overload. In patients with acute kidney injury but no evidence of fluid overload, diuretics have no benefit and can even be detrimental.

Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone with broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity, would be indicated if a urinary tract infection (UTI) was suspected. UTI is an important etiology to consider in a hospitalized patient with oliguria who has undergone recent instrumentation (foley catheter placement). However, this patient does not have any other symptoms consistent with UTI.

Most cases of postoperative oliguria are caused by decreased renal perfusion due to hypovolemia (resulting from intraoperative hemorrhage or insensible fluid losses) and renal afferent arteriole constriction (resulting from intraoperative catecholamine surge and increased sympathetic tone). The administration of intravenous crystalloid fluids (lactated Ringer's solution or normal saline) is the best next step in the management of a catheterized patient with postoperative oliguria and azotemia because increasing intravascular fluid volume via a fluid challenge will increase renal perfusion and thereby reverse these processes.

If the urine output does not increase after adequate fluid resuscitation, or if azotemia persists or worsens, a different cause of acute kidney injury (e.g., acute tubular necrosis, rhabdomyolysis, ongoing fluid losses, or, less likely, abdominal compartment syndrome) should be considered.

An abdominal CT would be indicated if intraabdominal bleeding is suspected. Significant intraabdominal hemorrhage can cause oliguria and prerenal azotemia. However, the absence of tachycardia and/or hypotension makes intraabdominal hemorrhage very unlikely. An abdominal CT would also be indicated if a deep surgical site infection (e.g., bacterial peritonitis, intraabdominal abscess) or anastomotic leak were suspected. These could both cause a decrease in urine output. However, other features such as tachycardia, hypotension, and/or fever would also be expected.

Tamsulosin is used to prevent or correct urinary retention in patients who have benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH). Patients with BPH are at risk of developing postoperative urinary retention, which can cause oliguria in a non-catheterized patient. This patient, however, has already been catheterized.

A suprapubic catheter would be indicated if the patient had postoperative urinary retention, failed a voiding trial, and could not be catheterized (e.g., due to severe prostatic enlargement). However, this patient has already been successfully catheterized and has no evidence of obstruction. Suprapubic catheterization confers no advantage in this scenario.

Reexploration would be indicated if this patient had features of hypovolemic shock (e.g., sudden deterioration, new-onset hypotension, poor peripheral pulses) or intraabdominal hemorrhage was strongly suspected. This patient is hemodynamically stable without signs or symptoms of acute intraabdominal pathology.

question_text: A 49-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of 2 episodes of vomiting bright red blood over the past 2 hours. His wife reports that he drank 1 bottle of vodka over the past 24 hours. During this time, he has had nausea but no bloody or tarry stool, and no abdominal pain. There is no history of similar episodes. The patient takes no medications. On arrival, he is awake but confused. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 110/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows ascites. On mental status examination, he is not oriented to person, place, or time. During the examination, the patient has another episode of vomiting blood. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL. Two large intravenous catheters are placed, and administration of intravenous fluids is begun. When vital signs are measured again, his pulse is 94/min and blood pressure is 109/80 mm Hg. He does not respond to verbal commands but withdraws appropriately to painful stimuli. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 49-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of 2 episodes of vomiting bright red blood over the past 2 hours. His wife reports that he drank 1 bottle of vodka over the past 24 hours. During this time, he has had nausea but no bloody or tarry stool, and no abdominal pain. There is no history of similar episodes. The patient takes no medications. On arrival, he is awake but confused. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 110/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows ascites. On mental status examination, he is not oriented to person, place, or time. During the examination, the patient has another episode of vomiting blood. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL. Two large intravenous catheters are placed, and administration of intravenous fluids is begun. When vital signs are measured again, his pulse is 94/min and blood pressure is 109/80 mm Hg. He does not respond to verbal commands but withdraws appropriately to painful stimuli. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Hematemesis in a patient with alcoholic cirrhosis raises concern for upper gastrointestinal bleeding from ruptured esophageal varices. In patients with ongoing hematemesis and/or altered mental status, immediate management should focus on resuscitation and stabilization.
learning_objective: Recognize upper gastrointestinal bleeding in a cirrhotic patient, and choose the most appropriate airway management.

answers.explanation_why: Placement of a nasogastric tube (NGT) for NGT lavage was formerly used to help determine whether the bleeding originated from the upper or lower gastrointestinal tract and whether it was ongoing. However, NGT placement is no longer recommended in patients with gastrointestinal bleeding because it has limited diagnostic and therapeutic value, causes significant discomfort, and carries the risk of complications (e.g., aspiration and airway compromise). Furthermore, this patient's ongoing bright red hematemesis suggests ongoing upper gastrointestinal bleeding, so NGT placement would provide no additional information. Additionally, patients with suspected esophageal variceal bleeding should not undergo NGT placement, which may exacerbate bleeding and further damage the esophagus.

Indications for transfusion of packed red blood cells in patients with acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding include hemodynamic instability refractory to fluid resuscitation, a hemoglobin concentration below 9.0 g/dL in high-risk patients (such as older individuals and patients with unstable coronary artery disease), and a hemoglobin concentration below 7.0 g/dL in low-risk patients. However, this patient continues to be hemodynamically stable and has a hemoglobin concentration of 9.5 g/dL.

Patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding who present with altered mental status and/or ongoing hematemesis are at increased risk for aspiration and should be intubated for airway protection. Endotracheal intubation decreases the risk of aspiration and can facilitate upper endoscopy in order to confirm the diagnosis and perform the definitive treatment (e.g., variceal band ligation).

In alcoholic cirrhosis, upper gastrointestinal bleeding raises suspicion for an esophageal variceal hemorrhage. A Mallory-Weiss tear is also an important differential diagnosis in this patient, as it is not known whether the hematemesis was preceded by emesis, retching, and coughing.

images.title: Management of acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding
images.description:
EGD: esophagogastroduodenoscopy
IV: intravenous
NPO: nil per os
UGIB: upper gastrointestinal bleeding

answers.explanation_why: Administration of omeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), suppresses acid production and significantly reduces the rate of rebleeding in patients with active upper gastrointestinal bleeding from peptic ulcers. Patients with ongoing hematemesis should not receive anything by mouth, particularly if they also have altered mental status. PPIs should be administered intravenously to avoid further risking aspiration. The cause of this patient's hematemesis is still unclear, so empiric treatment with a PPI is an important part of initial management, although it is not the next best step for this patient.

Nonselective beta blockers (e.g., carvedilol) are used as primary and secondary prophylaxis for bleeding in patients with esophageal varices that are at risk of rupturing, as these agents lower portal pressure. Carvedilol may be indicated once hemostatic control has been achieved, but it is not used in the acute management of upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

Upper endoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding who are hemodynamically stable. In particular, in patients with suspected esophageal variceal bleeding, endoscopic variceal ligation can achieve hemostasis and prevent recurrent bleeding. The goal for these patients is to perform endoscopy within the first 12 hours of presentation. However, this patient still has ongoing hematemesis and altered mental status, and, therefore, upper endoscopy is not the next best step.

question_text: Five minutes after arriving in the postoperative care unit following total knee replacement under general anesthesia, a 55-year-old woman is acutely short of breath. The procedure was uncomplicated. Postoperatively, prophylactic treatment with cefazolin was begun and the patient received morphine and ketorolac for pain management. She has generalized anxiety disorder. Her only other medication is escitalopram. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 95/52 mm Hg. A flow-volume loop obtained via pulmonary function testing is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Five minutes after arriving in the postoperative care unit following total knee replacement under general anesthesia, a 55-year-old woman is acutely short of breath. The procedure was uncomplicated. Postoperatively, prophylactic treatment with cefazolin was begun and the patient received morphine and ketorolac for pain management. She has generalized anxiety disorder. Her only other medication is escitalopram. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 95/52 mm Hg. A flow-volume loop obtained via pulmonary function testing is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The flattening of both the expiratory and inspiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop indicates fixed upper airway obstruction.
learning_objective: Recognize a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

answers.explanation_why: Rupture of an alveolar bleb would result in a pneumothorax, which could explain this patient's sudden dyspnea. Furthermore, her history of smoking increases her risk of COPD/emphysema, which in turn increases her risk of developing pneumothorax (either spontaneous or iatrogenic from hyperinflation during surgery). However, a pneumothorax would result in collapse of the affected lung and thus decreased total lung capacity, which is normal in this patient. Pneumothorax would not explain her abnormal flow-volume loop.

This patient has a history of anxiety, which puts her at increased risk for a panic attack. However, she lacks expected psychiatric features, such as intense fear or uncontrolled escalation of anxiety and/or worry, and a panic attack would not result in an abnormal flow-volume loop.

Respiratory muscle weakness can be caused by prolonged action of neuromuscular blocking agents, such as those used for induction of general anesthesia and intubation. However, the rapid shallow breathing in patients with respiratory muscle weakness would show a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume loop, characterized by decreased vital capacity, reduced inspiratory flow rates, and increased expiratory flow rates (in relation to the decreased vital capacity), in contrast to the blunting of both the inspiratory and the expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop seen in this patient.

images.title: Flow-volume loop in neuromuscular weakness
images.description: Weakness of the respiratory muscles results in reduced expiratory and inspiratory flows, reduced total lung capacity (∼ 5.5 L), and an increased residual volume (∼ 2 L).

answers.explanation_why: While this patient was recently given an opioid for pain control, which increases her risk of respiratory depression, it is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms because she has an increased respiratory rate (26/min). Additionally, this would not explain her flow-volume loop, severe hypotension, or tachycardia.

Bronchial hyperresponsiveness could indicate an acute exacerbation of underlying asthma, which would also manifest with dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, this is an unlikely diagnosis in a patient with no history of the disease. Additionally, the expiratory limb of the flow-volume loop in asthma is classically concave, in contrast to the blunting of both the inspiratory and the expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop seen in this patient.

images.title: Flow-volume loop in acute asthma
images.description: Expiratory flow is impaired by narrowed airways. Therefore, the peak expiratory flow rate is lower than normal with a slightly concave (scooped) curve toward the residual volume. The residual volume is abnormally high (∼ 2 L), as the narrowed airways have prevented a full expiration.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's sudden onset of shortness of breath, hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea following administration of a beta-lactam antibiotic (cefazolin) is consistent with anaphylaxis, which is a severe type I hypersensitivity reaction (HSR). These reactions are mediated by preformed drug-specific IgE binding to mast cells and basophils, which induces degranulation and release of vasoactive substances (e.g., histamine). The obstructive pattern on the flow-volume loop suggests significant laryngeal edema, a feature of anaphylaxis.

While this patient's type I HSR was most likely caused by exposure to cefazolin, it is important to consider other exposures that could have triggered the reaction, such as latex gloves used during the surgery.

images.title: Overview of flow-volume loops
images.description: A flow-volume loop is most commonly used as a graphical representation of spirometry testing. It plots inspiratory and expiratory flow (y-axis) against lung volume (x-axis) during a maximal forced expiration and a maximal inspiration.A (normal): At the beginning of the test, the patient has inhaled to total lung capacity of approx. 6.25 L (normal adult range: 6–6.5 L), and there is no flow. As the patient forcefully exhales, the flow quickly reaches a peak at approx. 10 L/s (normal adult range: 6–12.5 L/s) and then declines almost linearly until flow is zero at the residual volume of just over 1 L (normal adult range: 1–1.5 L). The patient then takes a full inspiration to return to total lung capacity.B (acute asthma): Expiratory flow is impaired by narrowed airways. Therefore, the peak expiratory flow rate is lower than normal with a slightly concave (scooped) curve toward the residual volume. The residual volume is abnormally elevated, as the narrowed airways have prevented a full expiration.C (emphysema): Expiratory flow is obstructed by the collapse of small airways. Therefore, the peak expiratory flow rate is lower than normal with a concave (scooped) curve toward the residual volume. The residual volume and total lung capacity are abnormally elevated due to the lung's increased compliance, decreased recoil, and air trapping.D (fixed upper airway obstruction): Expiratory and inspiratory flows are flattened and reduced, as they are impeded by the fixed obstruction.E (unilateral mainstem obstruction): The shape of the loop is normal, but peak expiratory and inspiratory flow rates are reduced, as air can only enter the open portion of the lung. The residual volume is greater than normal because air in the obstructed airway cannot be fully exhaled.F (obesity): Expiratory and inspiratory flows and total lung capacity are slightly reduced (compared to diagram A) because of the mechanical limitation of the obese chest wall to expand to full capacity.G (neuromuscular weakness): Respiratory muscle weakness results in reduced expiratory and inspiratory flows, reduced total lung capacity, and increased residual volume.H (fibrosis): Total lung capacity and peak expiratory and inspiratory flows are substantially decreased due to the lung's decreased compliance. Note that due to the enhanced elastic recoil of fibrotic lung parenchyma, expiratory flow is not decreased as greatly as lung volume.

images.title: Flow-volume loop - fixed upper airway obstruction

question_text: Two hours after admission to the hospital for rupture of membranes, a 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 40 weeks’ gestation is evaluated for the sudden onset of chills, dyspnea, confusion, and hypotension. The patient successfully underwent combined spinal-epidural anesthesia 1 hour ago. Her pregnancy was uncomplicated with the exception of a positive vaginal swab for group B streptococci 3 weeks ago, for which she received one dose of intravenous penicillin. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 70/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Physical examination shows labored breathing and thready pulses. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. The abdomen is nontender and the uterus is soft. Speculum examination shows pooling of bright red blood in the cervical canal. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 7.6 g/dL and an undetectable fibrinogen concentration. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition?
content_preview: Two hours after admission to the hospital for rupture of membranes, a 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 40 weeks’ gestation is evaluated for the sudden onset of chills, dyspnea, confusion, and hypotension. The patient successfully underwent combined spinal-epidural anesthesia 1 hour ago. Her pregnancy was uncomplicated with the exception of a positive vaginal swab for group B streptococci 3 weeks ago, for which she received one dose of intravenous penicillin. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 70/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Physical examination shows labored breathing and thready pulses. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. The abdomen is nontender and the uterus is soft. Speculum examination shows pooling of bright red blood in the cervical canal. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 7.6 g/dL and an undetectable fibrinogen concentration. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition?
hint: This patient presents with acute respiratory distress (dyspnea, tachypnea, decreased oxygen saturation), cardiovascular compromise (tachycardia, hypotension), altered consciousness (agitation, confusion), and hyperfibrinolysis (uterine bleeding, undetectable fibrinogen concentration) in the peripartum period.
learning_objective: Recognize amniotic fluid embolism.

answers.content: Apical ballooning of the left ventricle
answers.explanation_why: Apical ballooning of the left ventricle is a characteristic feature of stress cardiomyopathy (Takotsubo cardiomyopathy), which occurs as a result of catecholamine excess (e.g., due to acutely stressful events). Stress cardiomyopathy can manifest with symptoms of cardiac failure, including hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxia. However, this condition does not result in hemorrhage or a decreased fibrinogen concentration.

An allergic reaction to an anesthetic agent can cause anaphylaxis, which manifests with hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxia. However, this patient underwent anesthesia 1 hour prior to the onset of symptoms; anaphylaxis typically occurs within minutes after administration of the offending drug. In addition, this patient does not have other typical symptoms of anaphylaxis (e.g., urticaria, wheezing). Moreover, anaphylaxis does not result in hemorrhage or a decreased fibrinogen concentration.

answers.content: Amniotic fluid entering the endocervical veins
answers.explanation_why:
Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare, life-threatening complication of childbirth in which amniotic fluid enters the maternal circulation. AFE typically manifests during or shortly after labor or vaginal/cesarean delivery with abrupt onset of severe respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological compromise. Most patients progress to disseminated intravascular coagulation, which manifests with severe bleeding (e.g., from intravenous lines) and multiorgan dysfunction. AFE is mainly a clinical diagnosis. Treatment is supportive and involves respiratory and hemodynamic support, including the transfusion of blood products, to ensure adequate oxygenation and perfusion for both the mother and fetus. Up to 50% of patients with AFE die within an hour of onset.

The exact pathophysiology of AFE is not fully understood but likely involves an immune response (e.g., mast cell degranulation, complement system activation to fetal antigens that enter the maternal circulation). Risk factors for AFE include multiparity, age > 35 years, and complicated labor (e.g., placenta previa/abruption, forceps delivery, eclampsia).

answers.content: Anesthetic agent entering the subarachnoid space
answers.explanation_why: Spinal anesthesia involves injecting an anesthetic agent into the subarachnoid space. Injection of large amounts of anesthetic or changes in the positioning of the patient can result in total spinal anesthesia, a complication that manifests with hypotension, dyspnea, and hypoxia. However, this condition does not result in hemorrhage or a decreased fibrinogen concentration.

Systemic bacterial infections (e.g., sepsis) can manifest with hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxia and cause disseminated intravascular coagulation, which results in hemorrhage, a decreased hemoglobin concentration, and decreased fibrinogen concentration. However, patients with systemic bacterial infections typically have a fever and do not develop symptoms as rapidly as this patient, who developed sudden-onset chills, dyspnea, confusion, and hypotension within the past hour.

answers.content: Premature separation of the placenta from the uterus
answers.explanation_why: Premature separation of the placenta (placental abruption) can cause uterine hemorrhage and progress to hemorrhagic shock, which manifests with hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxia. Patients who have sustained a placental abruption typically have severe abdominal and/or back pain as well as severe uterine tenderness, but these symptoms may be concealed in this patient who underwent spinal-epidural anesthesia. In severe cases, placental abruption can lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation manifesting with hyperfibrinolysis. However, patients with placental abruption typically do not develop symptoms as rapidly as this patient, who developed sudden-onset chills, dyspnea, confusion, and hypotension within the past hour. Additionally, the uterus is usually rigid due to hypertonic contractions, not soft as in this patient.

question_text:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/70 mm Hg. Breath sounds are shallow. Examination shows multiple head contusions and a 3 cm x 3-cm soft hematoma on his left temporal region. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and infusion of 0.9% saline is started. A CT scan of the head shows a left-sided temporal bone fracture with an associated small left subarachnoid hemorrhage. He is taken to the neurosurgical intensive care unit for further management. The decision to intubate this patient was most likely based on which of the following combination of findings?

Eye opening
Verbal response
Motor response

A
To verbal command
Oriented
Obeys commands

B
To pain
Incomprehensible sounds
Abnormal flexion

C
To verbal command
Confused speech
Localizes pain

D
To pain
Incomprehensible words
Obeys commands

E
Open spontaneously
Inappropriate words
Withdraws from pain
content_preview: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/70 mm Hg. Breath sounds are shallow. Examination shows multiple head contusions and a 3 cm x 3-cm soft hematoma on his left temporal region. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and infusion of 0.9% saline is started. A CT scan of the head shows a left-sided temporal bone fracture with an associated small left subarachnoid hemorrhage. He is taken to the neurosurgical intensive care unit for further management. The decision to intubate this patient was most likely based on which of the following combination of findings? Eye opening Verbal response Motor response A To verbal command Oriented Obeys commands B To pain Incomprehensible sounds Abnormal flexion C To verbal command Confused speech Localizes pain D To pain Incomprehensible words Obeys commands E Open spontaneously Inappropriate words Withdraws from pain
hint: In cases of acute trauma, a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score ≤ 8 is an indication for urgent endotracheal intubation.
learning_objective: Recall the indications for intubation, and how the Glasgow Coma Scale score is calculated.

answers.explanation_why: A trauma patient who opens their eyes to verbal command, is oriented, and obeys commands would receive a GCS score of 14 (3 for eye opening, 5 for verbal response, and 6 for motor response). A GCS score of 14 indicates only mild head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation

A patient who opens their eyes to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, and has decorticate posture (or abnormal flexion) would receive a total GCS score of 7 (2 for eye-opening, 2 for a verbal response, and 3 for motor response). GCS assessment is part of the primary trauma survey in any trauma patient to evaluate neurological status, consciousness, and degree of brain injury. A GCS score of ≤ 8 indicates severe brain injury with a decreasing level of consciousness, which requires emergency endotracheal intubation to protect the patient's airway and reduce the risk of aspiration of gastric contents.

See “Glasgow coma scale” table.

A trauma patient who opens their eyes to verbal command, speaks confused or disoriented words, and localizes pain would receive a GCS score of 12 (3 for eye-opening, 4 for verbal response, and 5 for motor response). A GCS score of 12 indicates only moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.

A trauma patient who opens their eyes to pain and makes incomprehensible sounds but obeys commands would receive a GCS score of 10 (2 for eye-opening, 2 for verbal response, and 6 for motor response). A GCS score of 10 indicates moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.

A trauma patient who opens their eyes spontaneously, speaks inappropriate words, and withdraws from pain would receive a GCS score of 11 (4 for eye-opening, 3 for verbal response, and 4 for motor response). A GCS score of 11 indicates moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of upper abdominal pain, nausea, and nonbloody vomiting for the past hour. The patient rates the pain as an 8 to 9 on a 10-point scale. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoporosis. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. She drinks 5–6 alcoholic beverages daily. Current medications include glyburide, lisinopril, and oral vitamin D supplements. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Examination shows severe epigastric tenderness to palpation with guarding but no rebound; bowel sounds are normal. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows diffuse enlargement of the pancreas; no gallstones are visualized. The patient is admitted to the hospital and intravenous fluids and ketorolac are started. An hour later, the patient is still vomiting intermittently and rates the pain as a 9 on a 10-point scale. Physical examination of the abdomen shows no changes from the previous examination findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient’s pain?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of upper abdominal pain, nausea, and nonbloody vomiting for the past hour. The patient rates the pain as an 8 to 9 on a 10-point scale. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoporosis. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. She drinks 5–6 alcoholic beverages daily. Current medications include glyburide, lisinopril, and oral vitamin D supplements. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Examination shows severe epigastric tenderness to palpation with guarding but no rebound; bowel sounds are normal. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows diffuse enlargement of the pancreas; no gallstones are visualized. The patient is admitted to the hospital and intravenous fluids and ketorolac are started. An hour later, the patient is still vomiting intermittently and rates the pain as a 9 on a 10-point scale. Physical examination of the abdomen shows no changes from the previous examination findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient’s pain?
hint: This patient has acute pancreatitis (as evidenced by a diffusely enlarged pancreas on ultrasonography), which requires safe and effective pain management.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for severe acute pain in acute pancreatitis.

answers.explanation_why: Hydrocodone is a potent analgesic that is appropriate for treating severe pain but oral medications are not appropriate for patients who are actively vomiting. Parenteral analgesia is more appropriate for pain management in this patient.

Patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) with intravenous opioids (e.g., hydromorphone, fentanyl) is indicated in patients with severe acute pain (e.g., postoperative pain, malignancy pain, or pain resulting from acute pancreatitis, sickle cell crisis, or burn injuries). With PCAs, patients press a button that releases additional intravenous medication, allowing them to control the amount of analgesic they receive and minimizing the risk of underdosing. The pumps include a lockout period during which no further analgesic can be administered in order to avoid inappropriately high doses and reduce the risk of respiratory depression. Although opioids are known to cause sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, there is no evidence showing that opioids aggravate pancreatitis or worsen clinical outcomes.

images.title: Patient controlled analgesia (PCA) pump
images.description:
PCA pumps provide patient-controlled administration of opiates (epidural or intravenous) and local anesthetics (epidural). They may be used in the management of severe pain that is expected to be limited in duration, e.g., postoperative pain or malignancy pain.The display shows the current settings of the pump, which can be adjusted by medical staff as required:
– Continuous rate: the dosage of opiates that is automatically infused
– The PCA dose: the bolus dose of opiates that the patient can inject using the blue button on the remote control
– PCA lockout: the minimum amount of time that has to pass after a bolus dose before the pump will allow a further bolus to be administered
– 1-hour limit: the maximum amount of analgesia that the pump will dispense over an hour

answers.explanation_why: Most local anesthetics (e.g., bupivacaine) have low systemic absorption from the skin. Transdermal application of a local anesthetic only provides relief from nociceptive stimuli immediately near the site of patch application. Local anesthetics are not used to treat severe visceral nociceptive pain.

Ketamine plays a key role in emergency medicine because of its strong dissociative, sympathomimetic, and analgesic effects. Although this drug provides potent transient relief, continuous intravenous ketamine infusion causes profound sedation that requires continuous monitoring in a critical care unit. It would not be the most appropriate treatment plan for this patient.

In patients who are actively vomiting, oral medications are not appropriate. Also, acetaminophen is a mild analgesic. This patient who has severe persistent pain despite therapy with ketorolac requires a more potent analgesic for adequate pain relief. Finally, rather than receiving medication at a fixed interval, this patient will likely benefit from dose titration.

Anticonvulsants (e.g., gabapentin) are a useful adjunct for pain control in patients with chronic neuropathic pain but are not appropriate for the management of visceral nociceptive pain caused by pancreatitis. Moreover, in patients who are actively vomiting, oral medications are not appropriate.

Transdermal fentanyl is an effective adjunct for pain control in patients with chronic pain requiring opioids. However, transdermal fentanyl is not used in the initial management of acute severe pain, because it has a relatively slow onset of action and delivers a fixed dose of opioid. This patient requires a potent analgesic with a route of administration that allows for dose titration.
